“The leaders agreed on the importance of avoiding further regional escalation and ensuring calm in the West Bank.

“The Prime Minister committed the UK’s support for the Palestinian Authority in trying to establish peace and stability. They also discussed support for Gaza, including humanitarian aid and measures to protect civilians.
“More broadly, the Prime Minister and President Abbas agreed that the international community must intensify efforts to break the cycle of violence in Israel and the Occupied Palestinian Territories.
“The Prime Minister affirmed that the UK continues to support a two-state solution, with a Palestinian state existing alongside a safe and secure Israel.”

It comes as US President Joe Biden was reportedly considering a trip to Israel to show solidarity with the country after being invited by Israeli President Benjamin Netanyahu. A visit would follow that by US Secretary of State Antony Blinken who has been in the region attempting to ensure the conflict is contained and does not spread more widely throughout the Middle East.

title: Israel-Gaza conflict: At least 6 Britons have died and 10 are missing after Hamas attacks, Rishi Sunak says
lead: A number of Britons are also feared to have been taken hostage by the militant group and are being held in Gaza
author: Jane Merrick

body.text: Six Britons were killed by Hamas’ terrorist attacks in Israel and a further 10 are missing, Rishi Sunak has revealed.
A number of Britons are feared to have been taken hostage by the militant group and are being held in Gaza. The Prime Minister called for the “immediate release” of all hostages.

He told the Commons: “The terrible nature of these attacks means it is proving difficult to identify many of the deceased but with a heavy heart, I can inform the House that at least six British citizens were killed a further 10 are missing, some of whom are feared to be among the dead.”
Some of the family members of missing Britons watched the statement from the Commons gallery.

Mr Sunak said of the 10 who are missing, some are feared to be among the dead. The UK government is working with Israeli authorities to identify those killed and is supporting the families through their “unimaginable pain”.
Mr Sunak expressed his horror at the way Hamas had targeted civilians in Israel, with more than 1,400 murdered, over 3,500 wounded and almost 200 taken hostage.
He added: “The elderly, men, women, children, babes in arms, murdered, mutilated, burned alive. We should call it by its name: it was a pogrom.”

The Prime Minister spoke to Mahmoud Abbas, the leader of the Palestinian Authority, by telephone on Monday as he steps up the UK’s diplomatic efforts to ensure the conflict does not spread beyond Israel and Gaza.

Efforts are continuing from the PM and Foreign Office to persuade Egypt to open up the Rafah crossing, on its border with southern Gaza, to allow civilians to leave and more humanitarian aid to enter.
UK Border Force officials are already in Egypt working with the British embassy to assist British nationals leaving Gaza if and when the crossing opens.

Mr Sunak also announced that the UK’s humanitarian aid to the Palestinian territories will increase by more than a third, from £27m to £37m, to support civilians who have been forced to leave their homes in Gaza due to Israel’s bombardment.

title: I was awakened to the Israeli-Palestinian divide as a teen. Today, peace looks further away than ever
lead: My youth in an Israeli kibbutz was a stark introduction to the political tensions
author: Stefano Hatfield

body.text: On my first day volunteering in an Israeli kibbutz as a callow youth, I was instructed to clean out the graveyard. Toiling in the Middle Eastern heat, two military jets roared overhead. “Training exercise”, shrugged my supervisor. Hours later, I asked the same supervisor where I should deposit my rubbish bags.
“Oh, just over the fence,” he said to my puzzlement.
“Who is over the fence?”
“Oh, just Arabs…”

It was a stark introduction to a political divide, about which I had known nothing before my gap-year adventure. And, it was a rare moment of disdain among a Kibbutz community, who were among the most liberal, pro-Arab homeland of all Israelis I met.

I thought of the good people of Kibbutz Sarid this week, while reading in tears about the horrific Hamas attacks on Kibbutzim Be’Eri and Kfar Aza. Sarid is north of the West Bank, close to fabled Nazareth. Some of its 800-plus residents were already there in the 80s when this naive Croydon Catholic teen went in search of sun and sex.

There are 270 kibbutzim in Israel. They were originally set up as a utopian, agrarian collective community, built around shared facilities. Meals were taken en masse in the dining hall; kibbutniks and volunteers alike took turns in the collective kitchen and children slept in dorms on weeknights.
The foreign volunteers helped with the harvest. Sarid had a factory too, which made grindstones. I spent a memorably bleak fortnight, with my nose literally to a grindstone.

We picked pomelo, grapefruit and avocado at dawn before the sun became too fierce and sang the entirety of Carole King’s , up in the trees. But, boy, did we party. While we were introduced to the powerful Israeli aniseed liquour Arak, our hosts became familiar with my Goth music mix tapes.

We danced in the desert disco to the Banshees, as sullen Israeli teenage boys glowered at us, stoned, having returned from their weekly military service. It was hard labour by day, bacchanalian debauchery at night.

Only 23 kibbutzim still run a foreign volunteer programme. Many have since been privatised, Sarid included. They still provide subsidised accommodation for those born on the kibbutz, but children now sleep in family homes.
I heard from my American ex-girlfriend there this week. After a hedonistic fling, including a steamy trek around Egypt, she had dumped me for a “more appropriate” man, whom she later married.
She visited London last year. I had asked her if she would stay in Israel now she was divorced and hating the Netanyahu government, or return to the US? “It’s my home. What can I do?”.

That was her disconsolate message this week too when I checked in on her. At least, unlike many Palestinians trapped in Gaza, she could leave if she wished. She said the situation was a “heartbreaking nightmare” that was “only just beginning”. Last year, she had expressed doubt that Israel would ever achieve true peace without the dual-state solution that she, our kibbutznik friends, and many other Israelis advocate.
This week, peace looks further away than ever. Sadly, while we look on despairingly, it seems Sarid, Gaza, Israel and Palestine all face a harrowing and sorrowful short-term future.

title: Let’s stand by Israel – but we should not support a ground invasion
lead: As we enter unchartered territory it’s all the more important we think both operationally and strategically
author: Tobias Ellwood MP

body.text: Hamas’ intention is very clear: total war with Israel using any means – however barbaric – to lure Israel into a wider conflict that spreads across the Middle East.

It’s therefore right that Britain and America – indeed any nation that supports the international rule of law – backs Israel’s right to defend itself. The barbaric terrorist attacks Hamas has inflicted on hundreds of Israeli civilians removes any claim it may have to represent Gaza and the Palestinians there.
The objective is clear: the neutralisation of Hamas. But how this should be achieved requires more thought beyond the understandable urge for vengeance by launching a full ground invasion of Gaza.
As we enter unchartered territory it’s all the more important we think both operationally and strategically, considering not just one but four or five chess moves ahead.

Firstly, let’s take stock of the scale of planning Hamas has displayed and the depths of cruelty Hamas sunk to. It was not only trying to provoke Israel into mobilising its tanks but is suitably armed and able to engage them. Fighting in urban environments is the most challenging form of combat and favours the insurgent who in this case has likely spent many months preparing the tunnel system for any pending assault.

Secondly, Hamas cares little for ordinary Palestinians. It embeds itself amongst the civilian population. Israel is therefore falling into an almighty deliberate trap. Once the casualty numbers of ordinary Palestinians starts to ratchet up then any strategy to sever Hamas from the general population will be lost. Conflict will open up on new fronts in East Jerusalem and the West Bank.

Finally, this is Israel’s 9/11. So let’s learn from those terrible events in 2001 when, however well intentioned, major strategic errors were made in the name of defeating terrorism that we now know had profound consequences with enormous human and capital cost. International support eroded quickly.

There are no easy solutions here but vengeance alone is not a strategy. Any mission to remove Hamas must ensure the people of Gaza feel liberated from, not robbed of, their leadership. How that vacuum of governance is filled cannot be achieved by Israel alone. It should involve all its neighbours – Egypt, Jordan, UAE, Bahrain and Morocco – who signed the Abraham Accords.

These countries – and indeed any Muslim state – should be condemning Hamas’ hijacking of a peaceful religion to claim that such barbarism against the Jewish people will be rewarded in paradise. If this dangerous narrative is not addressed, then it will lead to another wave of extremism such as we saw after the twin tower attacks. This weekend, 21 years ago, a bomb was triggered in Bali by indoctrinated young locals which killed 202 people including my brother. Tensions are rising not just in the Middle East but also in city centres across the West.

This is not just Israel’s battle but the West’s too. For as long as Iran is able to continue flexing its proxy muscles across the region by bankrolling terrorist groups such as Hamas there will be no enduring peace. An opportunity was missed in 2020 when General Qasam Soleimani, head of the Iranian Islamic Revolutionary Guards, was taken out by a US drone. But the West blinked.
We should not just stand by but offer the wise strategic counsel that friends in highly volatile situations need to hear.

Given our history and connectivity to the region, in the grand theatre of Middle East diplomacy, the UK leverages quite a unique position to explore both the short and long term options, given the increasingly paralysed UN is ever closer to experiencing its “League of Nations moment”.

Conflict in the Middle East adds to an ever more complex and chaotic global threat picture with the prospect of serious miscalculation and escalation higher now than in decades. The necessary removal of Hamas may indeed require elements of hard power but guided by a sensible statecraft that avoids both mission creep and ultimately mission failure.

title: To lose moral consistency weakens the Palestinian cause
lead: It is as though we can only mourn deaths under one flag or another, but not both
author: Rachel Shabi

body.text: The initial disbelief soon turned to despair. As the world reeled at the scale of the Hamas attack on Israel last Saturday, many progressives were mortified at the willingness of some to cheer or endorse militants carrying out a deadly rampage through Israel’s south.

Over 1,200 Israelis were killed, indiscriminately, and in hellish scenes of slaughter. Thousands more are injured while more than 150, including the elderly and small children, have been taken hostage.

The response among a small but vocal minority of leftists? That this is Palestinian resistance against oppression. That the struggle for freedom is rarely bloodless. That a colonial state cannot be a victim and really, what did you think decolonisation meant?

Although small, this bit of the left encompasses campaigners, academics and protesters. It is as though we can only mourn deaths under one flag or another, but not both. Sections of the left refuse to criticise Hamas, seeing that as synonymous with criticising Palestinians. And Jewish and Israeli progressives are dismayed that the Hamas atrocity is met with this inability to acknowledge it for what it was: an abominable war crime.

It’s striking that such anguish is itself coming from long-time campaigners for the Palestinian struggle. I have seen anti-occupation campaigners, veteran Israeli human rights lawyers who launch legal fights for Palestinian rights, campaigners for Israel boycotts, ex-soldiers who speak out about Israeli military abuses and many more advocates for justice for Palestinian people express shock at some of the responses from progressive allies.

Israel is now pulverising Gaza, launching strikes that are flattening streets, killing entire families, cutting off power, water and supplies to a blockaded strip of 2.2 million people, of which half are children. Israel’s defence minister has said the country is fighting “human animals”, while an Israeli security official said Gaza would be turned into a “city of tents”.

The strip is already impoverished and near collapse after 16 years under siege and being subjected to several previous Israeli bombardments. That’s why some of the responses to the Hamas atrocities are hard to talk about right now: there is a terrible imbalance of power. Western leaders largely back Israel’s assault on Gaza. The clamour to inflict untold suffering on Palestinian people is deafeningly loud and coming from those with actual power or influence: politicians and media commentators.

This gaping hypocrisy has ever been the case, with Israel repeatedly given immunity by Western allies, while its military occupation continues to unleash violence, death and suffering upon Palestinians every day.
Still, the left’s response matters because it may exert some pressure to shape a future for the region, one being written in today’s uncertainty.

For decades, Israeli and Western leaders have dehumanised Palestinians, but the response cannot now be to dehumanise Israelis. Explaining the political context of the Hamas attacks and the principles of strategic armed struggle is a world away from endorsing an indiscriminate massacre. For if you think that war crimes from Hamas last Saturday are acceptable, how are you going to argue that war crimes from Israel today are not?

To lose moral consistency weakens the moral core of the Palestinian cause. To see these indiscriminate Hamas attacks as an acceptable outcome of Palestinian suffering is not a sign of solidarity; it is a form of moral relativism. To cast oppressed Palestinians as having special clearance for brutality is not a liberation struggle; it is specifically intertwining the cause with violence against civilians. And to say that all Israeli citizens are fair game (as I have seen repeatedly online) is a level of permissibility that is extraordinary. It is the same logic applied now to Palestinians in Gaza by the extremist Israeli government and its cheerleaders.

The Palestine solidarity movement is a just and urgent cause which has global grassroots support. Now many allies have vital questions about the political demands of this moment, of what the vision for the region’s future really looks like.

What, in the context of explaining those Hamas war crimes, does “decolonise” mean? If your argument is that all Jewish Israeli citizens are purely colonisers, then what does decolonisation even mean in the wider context of Israel and Palestine? Are Israeli Jews even viewed as a legitimate presence on the land in this scenario? At the moment, it does not sound like the term “decolonise” is used as an expression of any kind of shared, equal future for Palestinians and Israelis living in the region.

Successive Israeli governments have over decades closed off political, legal or diplomatic paths to resolution. Today, as it has been before, the Israeli government response is disproportionate violence, even though this cannot ever resolve the conflict.

In the current clamour for war – and just as was the case post-9/11 – there is no thought for the day after, of the consequences of raining deadly bombs over Gaza or “taking out” Hamas and leaving a vacuum where there was a ruling force.

Today, we must demand an end to the indiscriminate assault and siege of Gaza. We must urge for the release of Israeli hostages. But we must also draw a shared vision of what we want for the future of the people of the region, Israelis and Palestinians alike – not least so that we can fight for it.

title: There will be more NHS strikes under Labour – this is how Wes Streeting can solve them
lead: There are more battles with the British Medical Association on the horizon
author: Isabel Hardman

body.text: Can the NHS really be reformed? Usually, when someone poses this question, the first answer is: no, because voters are so religiously in love with it that they won’t allow it to be changed. This is obviously nonsense, because governments have spent the past 30 years moving the health service around like a child’s train set, and Brits spend almost as much time talking about the need for the NHS to improve as they do about the weather.
What anyone who talks about opponents of reform really means is not normal people, but the British Medical Association.

The BMA is busy fighting the Conservative government on pay at the moment, with both consultants and juniors continuing with strike action. Rishi Sunak has been exasperated by some of the negotiating positions these doctors have taken at the last minute, though, and openly complained about what he saw as unreasonable demands in his conference speech last week. Nonetheless, a deal is much closer for the consultants, who have always been the least hungry for walkouts.

Sunak thinks the strikes are being held largely to embarrass the Conservative government, with the BMA backing that line up by saying the attitude of the SNP government has meant Scotland has avoided walkouts. Meanwhile, this week shadow Health Secretary Wes Streeting argued at the Labour conference he could get the parties back round the table.

But the BMA’s junior members are now so wound up and emotionally exhausted by years of working in Covid and backlog chaos that it will be very difficult even after the strikes are resolved for any health secretary to do much with the health service without the trade union kicking off again. And Streeting isn’t proposing to quieten things down in the NHS. The two policy areas that dominated conference were planning reform and the health service. Keir Starmer promised in his own speech that Labour would be the party that “finally transforms the NHS”.

Streeting wants to rebalance the health service from a focus on acute, hospital-based care to primary and community services. It makes a lot of sense, but there is no indication from Shadow Chancellor Rachel Reeves, who gave a rather scary speech about fiscal discipline to the meeting in Liverpool, that she would be inclined to maintain the level of funding for acute while also pumping more money into the earlier end of the patient journey. So, the money must move, and that tends to mean closing hospitals, possibly even before they are rendered superfluous by a whizzy preventive system. Just wait for the BMA reaction to that.

There is a way through. The BMA isn’t the sum total of the medical world. If that were the case, the NHS simply wouldn’t exist, given that union fought tooth and nail against its creation back in the mid-40s. What got the health service over the line then, and might yet be its saviour this time around, is a group of far more august institutions.

The Medical Royal Colleges are a funny mix of educators and industry bodies. Doctors currently have to pass their exams in order to progress to consultant level and within specialties. They also bang the drum for their disciplines: more emergency medicine doctors, fewer targets in radiology, and so on. In 1948, they were critical to the very existence of the NHS. Labour’s health minister Nye Bevan made it his mission to woo the colleges, ensuring that they signed up early on to his plan for a new national health service.

They also largely spoke for hospital consultants rather than GPs. It was from his talks with the Royal Colleges that Bevan’s famous phrase “I stuffed their mouths with gold” hails: he got his plans over the line with those doctors by allowing them to continue private practice within NHS hospitals.

They then offered a solution to the continuing stand-off with the BMA in the final months before the service was due to start. Lord Moran, the president of the Royal College of Physicians, suggested an amendment to the National Health Service Act which would clarify that Bevan couldn’t force doctors to become full-time salaried employees of the state (a key fear of the profession). The BMA agreed.

The BMA always tends to march its members too far up a hill and require rescuing like this. In 2016, its strike action by juniors collapsed when leaked WhatsApp messages revealed the Junior Doctor’s Committee was plotting to “draw out” its battle with the Government and suggested it was fighting over pay, not patient safety, as it had told its members.

In the 70s, it lost huge credibility with its strikes over Barbara Castle’s plans to end the private practice Bevan had offered as a concession to get the service going. If the Royal Colleges move en masse in a pro-reform direction, maybe even talking doctors down from their current hill, then the rug would disappear from under the BMA once again. Any minister serious about the future of the NHS should learn not from the fight its founder had with its opponents, but from the charm offensive he conducted to ensure it exists at all.

title: Nearly half of voters want a general election by spring 2024, including a third of Tories, poll shows
lead: More than four in 10 voters believe Labour will secure a majority when the country does go to the ballot box
author: Richard Vaughan

body.text: Nearly half of the electorate want to see a general election by the spring of next year, including almost a third of those who voted Tory in 2019, polling shows.
Exclusive polling for  by BMG Research reveals that 48 per cent of the electorate want Rishi Sunak to call a general election within the next six months, rather than wait until next autumn.
And 29 per cent of people who voted Conservatives in the last election also want their say on who should form the next government sooner rather than later.
Some 28 per cent of voters would prefer to wait longer, beyond the next six months, to go to the polls, including 53 per cent of Conservative voters at the last election.
Labour will point to the figures as further evidence of the need for a general election by May next year, when local and mayoral elections are also held.
The party has been planning for a spring election, as it believes the Tories will go sooner than expected if the economic picture begins to improve, as is expected by the middle of next year.

But the Conservatives have repeatedly suggested that an election in late October or early November is more likely as it will give the Prime Minister the most time to reap any benefits from lower inflation and potential economic growth.
It coincides with increasing doubts among voters of the Tories’ chances of staying in power when the election is eventually held.

According to the survey of more than 1,500 British adults between 11 and 12 October, two-fifths – 44 per cent – of the country believe Labour will secure a majority at the next election, including nearly a third – 30 per cent – of Tory voters.

Just 17 per cent of the electorate believe the Conservatives are on course for a majority, which will come as little surprise given the party remains 13 points behind Labour on voting intention. Even fewer, 15 per cent, believe there will be a hung parliament, among them 20 per cent of Tory voters.

Perhaps most worryingly for Mr Sunak is the sizeable belief among the electorate in the need for a change in government. The results show more than a third – 34 per cent – of those who intend to vote Labour at the next election gave this as a reason for their decision, including 45 per cent of those who had voted Tory in 2019.

More than a quarter – 27 per cent – said they were planning to vote for Sir Keir Starmer’s party because there were “no better options”, revealing a lack of support for the Labour leader’s offer to the country.
Just 18 per cent said Sir Keir was the best candidate for the job of Prime Minister, while only 16 per cent said Labour was best suited to tackle the challenges facing the country.

In a further boost for Labour, polling by Savanta revealed that the party is now neck and neck with the SNP in Scotland with both on 35 per cent, the first time this has happened since the Independence Referendum in 2014.

title: Labour’s handling of antisemitism has dramatically improved under Starmer, poll says
lead: Sixty per cent of people surveyed said Jeremy Corbyn handled anti-Semitism complaints badly, compared to 18 per cent for Sir Keir Starmer
author: Poppy Wood

body.text: Labour’s handling of antisemitism has dramatically improved under Sir Keir Starmer’s leadership compared to his predecessor Jeremy Corbyn, polling reveals.

A poll by BMG for showed that more people think Sir Keir has handled the issue well than badly since becoming Leader of the Opposition. Twenty-nine per cent of voters surveyed said they supported his approach to accusations of antisemitism within the Labour Party, compared with 18 per cent who said he has mismanaged the situation.

It marks a dramatic improvement compared to Mr Corbyn’s leadership. A separate poll by BMG in 2018 while the former Labour MP was in charge showed that 60 per cent of people thought he mishandled antisemitism accusations within the party, while only 8 per cent supported him.

More than half of respondents said they either didn’t know how Sir Keir has handled antisemitism within Labour or that they had a neutral view on the subject, up from 31 per cent during Mr Corby’s reign. BMG said it suggested the issue of antisemitism in the party “is not as prominent in public perception as it once was”.

It comes after Sir Keir received two standing ovations during his keynote speech at the Labour Party conference in Liverpool earlier this week for offering his unequivocal support to the Jewish community.
Speaking two days after Hamas launched the bloodiest attack on Israel for 50 years, Sir Keir said Labour was now a “new party” that had “ripped antisemitism out by its roots”.

“I am shocked and appalled by the events in Israel,” the Labour leader told delegates in the conference hall. “I utterly condemn the senseless murder of men, women and children, including British citizens, in cold blood by the terrorists of Hamas.”
Sir Keir’s comments earned him praise from the Jewish community for working to tackle antisemitism within the Labour party.

In a joint statement, the Board of Deputies, the Jewish Leadership Council, the Community Security Trust and the Jewish Labour Movement said Sir Keir “has already achieved in four days more than his predecessor in four years in addressing antisemitism within the Labour Party”.

“This has certainly been a good start. If the new Labour leadership continues in this way, we can work together to make the changes that will make Labour a proudly anti-racist party once again,” they added.
Mr Corbyn was suspended as a Labour MP in 2020 after the party was found guilty of unlawful discrimination under his leadership.

It followed a report by the Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC), which found “specific examples of harassment, discrimination and political interference” relating to antisemitism within Labour while Mr Corbyn was leader.
The report added that antisemitism within the party “could have been tackled more effectively if the leadership had chosen to do so”.
The EHRC reviewed 70 complaint files relating to antisemitism in the party between March 2016 and May 2019 and concluded that there were 23 instances of political interference by Labour staff.

It included the party’s handling of a complaint made about Mr Corbyn in 2018, after the former Labour leader posted a statement in support of an artist who had produced an antisemitism mural in east London.

Staff from Mr Corbyn’s office were found to have called for the case to be dismissed, and directly emailed the party’s governance and legal unit saying it fell “well below the threshold required for investigation”.

Labour was also found to have breached the Equality Act in several cases, with the EHRC concluding that party agents were engaged in “committing unlawful harassment” including using “antisemitic tropes and suggesting that complaints of antisemitism were fake or smears”.

Responding to the report in 2020, Sir Keir said it was “a day of shame for the Labour party” and apologised to the Jewish community. He pledged to implement the report’s recommendations in full and promised a “culture change” within Labour.

By that point, Sir Keir had already set about removing close allies of Mr Corbyn accused of antisemitism. It included then-shadow Education Secretary Rebecca Long-Bailey, who was sacked in June 2020 after sharing an article containing an antisemitic conspiracy theory.

Mrs Long-Bailey had retweeted an interview with actor and Labour supporter Maxine Peake, who claimed the police officers responsible for George Floyd’s murder learnt their tactics “from seminars with Israeli secret services”. The former Labour MP said she had not meant to endorse all aspects of the article.
Several Jewish Labour members who left the party under Mr Corbyn’s leadership have also returned since Sir Keir took the helm.

Luciana Berger, the former Labour MP for Liverpool Wavertree, accepted an invitation from Sir Keir to rejoin the party in February. She quit in 2019, citing years of antisemitic abuse and harassment, but said earlier this year the party “has turned a significant corner under [Sir] Keir’s leadership”.
However, others have suggested Sir Keir still has some way to go to show Labour is a new party.

The Labour leader came under fire from the Tories earlier this week when he refused to suspend Apsana Begum, a staunch supporter of Mr Corbyn, after she posed for a picture at a Palestine Solidarity Campaign stand at Labour’s party conference. Shadow minister Afzal Khan did the same on Monday.

A Shadow Cabinet source said Labour was poised to stamp out any instances of antisemitism or other ill discipline over the Israel crisis, but that the party was now much better equipped to deal with the issue due to having a clear zero-tolerance policy.

title: Liberal Democrats oppose Labour’s VAT plan for private schools in fresh dividing line between parties
lead: The third party said it would not support the policy of imposing VAT on school fees which has been promised by Labour
author: Hugo Gye

body.text: The Liberal Democrats have opened a fresh dividing line with Labour by speaking out against the party’s policy of imposing VAT on private schools.
Sir Keir Starmer has suggested that the new levy on school fees will be one of his top priorities if he wins the next general election.
As  revealed this week, Labour intends to introduce the policy as soon as it takes power – raising the prospect that it would take effect as soon as next academic year.
But the Lib Dems said they opposed the policy, although they would support a review of charitable status among schools due to fears that some do little to help their local area.

A spokesman said: “The Liberal Democrats do not support ending the VAT exemption. We do think some private schools benefit from lower taxes due to charitable status even though they perform almost no charitable act on behalf of the community – so charitable status does need to be reviewed so that it only rewards schools that do real community work.”
The intervention opens a rare division between the two main Opposition parties ahead of next year’s general election.

In the event of a hung Parliament, Sir Keir is likely to seek support from the Lib Dems to operate a minority government. The third party has not yet said which policy concessions it would demand in return.

Neither party has openly said that they would seek to do a deal as part of a so-called “progressive alliance”. But both have ruled out entering any sort of agreement with the Conservatives or the Scottish National Party, suggesting that there would be no other option to form a stable government if Labour falls short of a majority.
Lib Dem demands would almost certainly include some sort of electoral reform, and more funding for health which has been at the centre of the party’s recent campaigning.

It is not yet clear whether it would request a veto over certain Labour policies – or whether Sir Keir would consider dropping the private schools VAT plan given how much he has talked about it since becoming leader.
In an interview with  on Friday Lib Dem deputy leader Daisy Cooper pointedly did not rule out a post-election pact with Labour.
The Liberal Democrats are currently seeking to win voters from the Conservatives in wealthy, liberal parts of the country such as suburban areas of South-East England.
Under the Coalition Government between 2010 and 2015, the party was a fervent supporter of educational reforms but did not push for a crackdown on the privileges available to private schools.

Labour’s reforms to the tax treatments of private schools are intended to fund a number of improvements to state education, including the recruitment of extra teachers and more mental health support for pupils.
They are one of the few tax increases that Sir Keir and Rachel Reeves, the shadow Chancellor, have approved as they push to appeal to middle-class voters.

title: Reports of the death of the SNP may be greatly exaggerated
lead: The party gathers for its conference this weekend after a defeat and a defection. Can it bounce back?
author: Paul Waugh

body.text: When SNP MP Dr Lisa Cameron announced her sudden defection to the Conservatives on Thursday, Scotland’s First Minister Humza Yousaf joked that it was “the least surprising news I’ve had as leader of the SNP”.

Rather than focus on Cameron’s claims of being “ostracised” for speaking out over the party’s handling of the sexual misconduct of fellow MP Patrick Grady, Yousaf appeared to play down the defection as effectively a personality clash.

But his wry reference to all the surprises he’s faced was an admission that the SNP has been rocked by a series of even bigger shocks over recent months, not least the arrest of Nicola Sturgeon and her husband Peter Murrell in a police investigation into the party’s finances. (The SNP has repeatedly denied any wrongdoing during the months-long police inquiry. Sturgeon has also personally denied any wrongdoing. Neither has been charged.)

And as the SNP meets in Aberdeen for its annual conference this weekend, it may struggle to shrug off the sense of unease and divisionthat has jolted it from years of steady dominance of both Scotland’s Westminster seats and its Holyrood Parliament.

One week on from Labour’s stunning victory in the Rutherglen and Hamilton West by-election, with a 20 per cent swing that could result in the wipeout of many SNP seats in a general election, Yousaf certainly has a tough job on his hands.

When Alex Salmond and Sturgeon were riding high, the party appeared to be a model of unified electoral professionalism. Its critics argue that unity, like the independence cause itself, papered over the cracks and divisions over exactly what kind of politics it stood for.

MSPs Fergus Ewing, Alex Neil and, most significantly, Kate Forbes, are all staying away from this year’s conference. Ewing has urged his party to ditch the “hard left extremists” of the Green Party, as well as “unpopular” policies on the environment and trans rights.

Neil has called for Forbes, who was only narrowly beaten by Yousaf in the leadership race (52 per cent to 48 per cent) earlier this year, to be made deputy First Minister to heal any splits and unite the membership. Forbes certainly represents a more rural and centre-right politics than the First Minister, who has followed Sturgeon’s lead in pitching to former Labour voters in the urban Central Belt. The differences were starkly highlighted during a leadership debate when Yousaf said: “The Tories don’t fear you, Kate, they’re rooting for you.”

Lisa Cameron’s defection to the Conservatives undeniably gifts Labour a fresh attack line of “vote SNP, get a Tory”. Many in Keir Starmer’s party have long derided the SNP as “the Tartan Tories” because 11 of their MPs did a deal with Margaret Thatcher’s Opposition to win the no confidence vote that toppled James Callaghan in 1979.

One of the biggest calls that the SNP now has to make is whether to drop Yousaf’s strategy of treating the next general election as a “de facto” referendum on independence. Several of its MPs, left and right, think that’s just too risky given that Labour is on the rise.

Only last month, a new report by the Institute for Government and Cambridge University’s Bennett Institute described such a strategy as an “egregious” example of political deviation of usual norms on the constitution.

Worse still for the SNP, the study yoked Yousaf’s approach to Boris Johnson’s claim that he should not be ousted from office because he had a personal mandate from the voters, even though the UK elects MPs, not presidents. Among those on the report’s advisory panel was Brenda Hale, the former Supreme Court judge who ruled Johnson’s prorogation illegal.

If the SNP were to ditch its “de facto” referendum plan, it could focus on the Holyrood elections in 2026 as the real testing ground for independence. If there is a Labour government next year, the party will argue that’s all the more reason to send SNP MSPs to Edinburgh as a counterweight.

Although the party has for years been sustained by deep Scots antipathy to being governed by Tories in London, many in its ranks believe that voters will quickly realise that life is no better under a Labour government in Westminster. Far from killing off the independence dream, Starmer could fuel it, they argue.

It’s notable too that even though support for the SNP has fallen dramatically, support for independence is still historically pretty high, reaching 47 per cent recently. If, as expected, its punchy and witty Westminster leader Stephen Flynn becomes an MSP after 2026, he could be the man to lead the cause.

Of course, there still remains the problem that independence simply can’t happen unless a Westminster government first agrees to hold a new referendum. Even if Labour refuses to do so (and it has wavered in the past), the irony is that it could be the “Conservative and Unionist Party” (to give them their official title) that grants a fresh plebiscite.

If the Tories were to oust Starmer from No 10 at a general election in 2028 or 2029, some of them may never again want a situation where Labour uses its Scottish seats to form a government.If Scotland were to become independent, at a stroke it becomes much harder for Labour to ever form a majority south of the border.

While no Tory MP will publicly admit as much, there has long been a strain of opinion within the party that would shrug its shoulders if Scots were to go their own way, leaving behind a Tory-dominated England and a rump of Labour MPs in Wales.

The other irony is that the Scottish independence cause has parallels with the Brexit cause, though neither wants to admit them. Both assert national sovereignty and self-determination above all other factors, both want to be free from a union they believe is an historic mistake.
And just as 70s opponents of the Common Market were vindicated by a second referendum after years of setbacks, so too could Scottish “better off outers” achieve their aim in the 2030s.

If the Police Scotland investigation fails to find sufficient evidence, if the next UK government fails to improve the lot of Scots, and if the SNP retains power in Holyrood, Westminster may have to grant another referendum. To paraphrase Mark Twain, reports of the death of the SNP may be greatly exaggerated – and predictions of the demise of the independence dream even more so.

title: Rishi Sunak’s image as a numbers man is now in question after this scathing report
lead: Voters may just see it as yet another sleight of hand from a Government that has already lost their trust
author: Paul Waugh

body.text: If revenge is a dish best served cold, Rishi Sunak’s recent attacks on the Climate Change Committee (CCC) got some very chilly just deserts yesterday.

Three weeks after the Prime Minister’s great “reset” on net zero, including false claims that the Committee wanted a meat tax or compulsory car sharing, it has delivered a withering verdict on how off track the Government’s green policies really are.

The statutory watchdog, whose job is to independently assess how the UK meets its legal duty to achieve net zero emissions by 2050, pulled off the trick of being impeccably measured yet quietly devastating in its conclusions.

The Committee praised ministers for the new UK Emissions Trading Scheme which has tightened limits on greenhouse gas to align with the net zero cap, and for a new project to electrify steel production in Port Talbot, South Wales.
It also welcomed the Government’s decision to finally confirm its “zero emissions” mandate, which will fine car firms that fail to produce a set quota of electric cars and vans from next year.

But the watchdog skewered Sunak’s decision to ditch plans to force landlords to insulate their homes, pointing out the recent offshore wind auction failed miserably and warned that there was  “a substantial policy gap” to getting to the UK’s 2030 climate goals, let alone 2050.

Most brutal was the blunt verdict that “recent policy announcements were not accompanied by estimates of their effect on future emissions, nor evidence to back the Government’s assurance that the UK’s targets will still be met”.

Sunak prides himself on being a numbers man, but here was the independent, expert body basically saying his numbers don’t add up. The CCC verdict felt like a broadside at the evidence-free basis for his boasts that Britain’s climate ambitions would still be fulfilled.

In ideological terms, it’s perfectly credible for the PM to suggest that, in his words, “banning things” is a less effective way of hitting targets. Yet in practical terms (and he says he’s a pragmatist), he has produced no alternative roadmap for hitting them. A Brexit-style “we’ve had enough of experts” rhetoric won’t work on climate science, either.

Just as damaging, the Committee suggested the PM’s moves to delay and water down previous commitments would put up bills for drivers and renters, the very opposite of his claim to be acting to ease the burden on ordinary people.

Costs for renters will go up by £2bn a year (because of heat lost through draughts), and costs for motorists will increase by £6bn (because they will be missing out on cheaper second-hand electric vehicles, which cost less to power than petrol or diesel cars).

Sunak had already undermined his own case by making false suggestions that people were being asked to “rip out” their boilers. Energy firms have also offered new heat pumps that run at half the cost of gas boilers, saving £500 a year in running costs.

Shaun Spiers, of the Green Alliance think tank, said: “In sacrificing long-term climate policies for short-term political gains, the PM is damaging the economy and throwing away the opportunity to cut costs for struggling households. He should listen to the government’s advisers rather than thinking, apparently on a wish and a prayer, that he knows better.”

As to the wider expense of delays, the Office for Budget Responsibility (an independent watchdog the PM knows he has to like, given Liz Truss’s trashing of it led to her downfall) warned this summer that if there is “a late and abrupt process of decarbonisation, the fiscal costs could be greater still”.

Backing off net zero poses a threat to the PM’s war on inflation too. Bank of England interest rate-setter Megan Greene said last month that uncertainty around environmental policy in Britain was hurting investment and would likely make inflation more volatile in future.

City financiers, normally the kind of audience to whom the former Chancellor listens, have also said that Sunak’s shift risks undermining UK competitiveness internationally. Big firms like Aviva, and Jupiter Asset Management, which hold more than £1.5 trillion in combined assets, warned against “backsliding”.

The impact on global emissions is a risk too. At the forthcoming COP28 climate talks, Sunak will have a tough task persuading other countries they should increase their net zero commitments if he’s backing off his own.

The politics of all this are nowhere near as positive as the PM thinks either. Yes, his claims that he would save people money from delaying bans on petrol cars and gas boilers were popular among some. But focus groups suggest voters will see the U-turn as either yet another broken promise or a mark of incompetence, or both.

After Nigel Farage’s appearance at the Tory conference, moderate Tory MPs fear their party is already losing key floating voters. By contrast, Keir Starmer leaned into his vow to “speed up” the green transition to cut bills and create jobs.

The Conservative Environment Network’s Deputy Director John Flesher tells me: “The Labour Party is making climate action a big part of its pitch to voters. Conservatives cannot afford to lose their grip on the net zero narrative and must present a compelling, market-based route to net zero.”

If Sunak’s net zero messaging fails to rescue him at the next election, it may help Tory environmentalists to make their case that climate scepticism is not just economically damaging but electorally toxic too.

However, there is also the risk that a party out of office will be even less bound by the hard realities of governance and may veer into greater Trump-style opposition. Politicians like Suella Braverman argue the 2050 net zero date is an “arbitrary” target, even though it is determined by international scientific consensus as a point of no return for the planet.

All this will come to a head even before the PM heads off to Dubai for COP28 next month. The Energy Minister confirmed last month that the Government will meet its legal obligation to update MPs with a response to the CCC’s latest progress report “by the end of October”.

And here’s where things could get interesting. I’m told that the chatter in Whitehall is that Sunak and his new Energy Security Secretary Claire Coutinho are looking closely at effectively reconfiguring carbon budgets to accommodate changes in policy.
Under Section 17 of the 2008 Climate Change Act, Coutinho has the power to “carry forward” emissions from one five-yearly carbon budget to another.

When Theresa May tried to pull this trick in 2018, she was told by the CCC that couldn’t use low economic growth (and its lower emissions) to bail her out from future targets.  She did it anyway, while accepting the advice that the surplus should not be used to reduce the ambition of the next budget.

But a live debate is going on behind the scenes on whether it is legally possible to effectively use the UK’s previous overperformance to help boost the current budget for 2023 to 2027. That would be sure to trigger possible legal challenges.

The Energy Security Department tells me that the Climate Change Act does allow flexibilities, including carry-over between carbon budgets but stresses that “no decisions have been taken on use of these flexibilities for future years”. That’s not exactly ruling the idea out.

But while creative accounting on UK net zero targets may look like some lovely wheeze to some in No 10, the public may just see it as yet another sleight of hand from a Government that has already lost their trust. Reconfiguring the figures while the planet burns may not be a great look.

Economist John Maynard Keynes once argued that governments should solve problems in the short run, rather than wait for market forces to fix things over the longer term. Why? Because “in the long run, we are all dead.” On climate change, that warning applies even more powerfully and literally. If the PM tries to conjure his way out of net zero targets, the voters may give a similarly pithy verdict.

title: Careful Keir – you’re taking your eye off public services
lead: If health, education and childcare don’t get an emergency injection of funds, public sector staff may think the cavalry will never arrive
author: Paul Waugh

body.text: Every now and again, party conferences feature speeches from non-politicians that really stop you in your tracks.

On Wednesday, Nathaniel Dye, a 37-year-old teacher with stage-4 incurable bowel cancer, told the Labour gathering in Liverpool that he was back in the classroom because “I can’t think of a better use for the time I have left”.

Nathaniel, who runs ultramarathons for cancer charities, was painfully blunt about the disease. “In five years it’s all but certain that I will be dead: no career, no family, no opportunity, cancer has robbed me of a promising future.”

But what made his testimony even more tragic was that he felt it was preventable. That prognosis “might not be quite as bleak” if the NHS had more capacity in the system for tests, scans, biopsies and treatments, he said. Worst of all, he  waited 15 weeks between being contacted by his GP to receiving chemotherapy – a journey that is meant to take just 62 days.

Shadow Health Secretary Wes Streeting, himself a cancer survivor, was visibly moved by Nathaniel’s words as he started his own set piece speech to the conference. Referring to the “deep sense of injustice that the NHS didn’t reach you in time”, he said he was “determined to make sure that the NHS doesn’t fail people like Nathaniel any more”.

With NHS waiting lists standing at a record 7.7 million, 700,000 higher than when Rishi Sunak became Prime Minister last year, there’s no question that the state of the health service is a key reason the Conservatives are hugely unpopular right now.

As Nathaniel so eloquently proved, those cold statistics have an awful human cost. The new plan unveiled by Streeting and Keir Starmer this week, to pay NHS staff extra to work weekends to clear the backlog, would certainly make a start in easing the misery felt by those with both chronic and life threatening conditions.

Labour say that the £1.1bn proposal, funded by a £3.2bn a year crack down on wealthy “non-doms”, would provide an extra two million operations scans and appointments in the first year. It would be a nationwide extension of good practice operated in some pioneering NHS trusts.
But, in an echo of Starmer’s own line about “a reforming state not a chequebook state”,  Streeting was just as resolute about the need for longer-term reform of the system.
He had a persuasive argument that his line that the NHS “must reform or die” should not been seen as a threat but as a stark choice.
His criticisms of “an analogue system in a digital age, a sickness service not a prevention service”, and that our ageing society “threatens to bankrupt our NHS”, all had force too.

Yet it will take reform and investment to get the health service back on track. And although the party is more comfortable talking about the former rather than the latter right now, it’s not a conversation it will be able to avoid either in the next election campaign or in government.

While this week’s £1.1bn will make an impact, it is a tiny percentage of the NHS’s overall budget. That’s why Sir Julian Hartley, chief executive at NHS Providers said that “reform” should not be seen as a magic bullet. “The remedy will require sustained investment, an end to chronic workforce shortages, more support to meet growing demand,” he said.

Just one indication of the thin nature of Labour’s offer is its new “Fit For The Future Fund”, which would provide an extra £171m a year to double the number of CT and MRI scanners in the NHS over the course of a Parliament. That’s just a fraction of the number needed.

Indeed, for all the rhetoric this week, it’s notable that public services like health and education have taken a back seat at the party conference, relegated behind housebuilding and energy and transport infrastructure.

While Streeting and shadow Education Secretary Bridget Phillipson were relegated to the “graveyard” slots in a partly-attended hall on the final day, much more significant was that they were given relatively small pots of money.

Of course, radical planning reform appeals to the party because it’s developers who will be stumping up the cash. But the massive £28bn a year Labour plans to invest in net zero projects and jobs is a startling contrast to the small sums it has so far pledged for capital spending on the NHS or education.

This matters all the more because capital spending on the NHS was so squeezed by David Cameron’s austerity programme. Talk to anyone in the health service and they will say that a failure to invest in diagnostics, scans and IT are as much of a failure as the woeful understaffing of the past decade.

It’s worth saying that the current Government has its own sleights of hand when it comes to funding key public services too. When Rishi Sunak this summer announced a new workforce plan for much needed extra doctors, nurses, midwives and other staff, he failed to say how he would fund it.

A similar trick occurred when the Tories last year scrapped their own Health and Social Care Levy, which was meant to raise £12bn a year for both NHS treatment catch up and social care. One of the least noticed elements of Kwasi Kwarteng’s mini-Budget was his line that despite the axing of the tax, the additional funding would “be maintained at the same level.”

If Labour had done either of those two things, it would have been hammered for making “unfunded” spending commitments. Yet in the real world, room was and will be found within the overall Government spending envelope – which is exactly what Labour may do in coming years.

Phillipson has made her own powerful case for reforms in education, particularly early years. A recent cross-party report warned Jeremy Hunt’s £4bn for childcare is inadequate to meet the challenge of stagnant funding and a recruitment crisis among a low paid workforce.

Yet although Starmer and Shadow Chancellor Rachel Reeves have repeatedly said how vital childcare is to both economic growth and family finances, Phillipson has not yet been given any cash to find an alternative to the Government’s plans.

Starmer rails against the Tories’ “sticking-plaster” politics, but his line would have more power if he acknowledged that he needs to apply some serious first aid, plus big bandages, to stabilise our public services. At least until extra cash is released from either reform or a booming economy.

It may be that Labour puts more meat in its election manifesto, but some suspect Starmer and Reeves will wait until they’re in office when they can assess how much room they have in a spending review for extra cash.

The difficulty is that many of those who work in the public sector, as well as those who rely on public services, will be impatient for change after so many years of decay. Many NHS staff and teachers are so burnt out they are leaving in droves, but others have been waiting for “the cavalry” to arrive in the shape of a Labour government.
If the party fails to inject emergency funds needed before its much-trumpeted economic growth returns, those staff may feel let down all over again. Patients like Nathaniel Dye can’t wait either.
Labour used to talk about “rescue and reform”, but this week the rhetoric about reform took precedence over the rescue job required.

Tony Blair motivated voters in 1997 with an eve-of-election rallying cry that they had “24 hours to save the NHS”. Unless Starmer shows a similar urgency, his new government would risk losing the very people it needs most.

title: Even in the darkness, we cannot give up on the hope of peace for Israel and Gaza
lead: A safe Jewish homeland can exist alongside Palestinian self-determination
author: Ian Dunt

body.text: Sometimes the horror overtakes you. You can feel it gathering up inside you, beneath the skeleton. This week it felt too large to bear, as if the scale of tragedy is about to overwhelm our critical functions.
The terror that Hamas unleashed on Israel is both the same and not the same as the terror that we have seen elsewhere in the world.

The most obvious comparison is perhaps the Paris attacks of 2015. The resonance lies not in the numbers – the attack on Israel is much larger – but with the Bataclan theatre, where 90 concert-goers were killed. In Israel, 260 bodies have been recovered from the Supernova festival. They were hunted down and shot. They were fired upon as they attempted to escape. They were put on motorbikes as hostages and driven away. The same images, a continent apart: young people, free and alive, murdered by barbarians.

But there’s a difference in the global emotional response to these events. When the Bataclan was attacked, people were united and vocal in their dismay. When Supernova was attacked, some people gathered with Palestinian flags in cities around the world, with the clear implication of support for what had happened. The commissioning editor for a left-wing website claimed that “the struggle for freedom is rarely bloodless and we shouldn’t apologise for it”. (She deleted her tweet today and apologised.)
In other cases, the response was more subdued. And for many Jewish people, that silence itself is telling. It is an echo of the silence which has often greeted violence against them.

In Nazi Germany, there were open protests against the murder of the mentally ill and physically disabled in 1940, led by the Catholic church. It eventually forced Hitler to terminate the programme. The same thing did not happen for the Jews. We have consistent contemporary reports of German public discomfort with Nazi attacks on Jews, particularly after the Night of Broken Glass. But no one really spoke up. No one organised protests. Church leaders did not get involved. And so it was allowed to continue to its genocidal end.
Silence in the face of violence against Jews is not separate to antisemitism. It is the precondition for it.

There is also a crucial distinction in the intent of the attacks. When terrorists struck France, they were not trying to wipe out the French nation. They were not trying to eradicate the French race. But that is precisely what Hamas wants to do – they aim for the destruction of the Jewish state and the extermination of the Jewish race. Each act of terrorism is not equivalent. One of them is murderous and barbaric. The other is existential.

If Britain had been attacked this weekend, in the most savage and sadistic way imaginable, resulting in the murder of more than 1,000 people, we would be unable to contain our emotional devastation. We would demand action. And we would never be able to forgive those, in other countries, who wanted to dismiss our suffering, or talk about “root causes”, or to ignore it completely.

But the Bataclan attack is also instructive for a different reason. After it took place, France launched limited airstrikes against Isis in the Syrian city of Raqqa. Israel’s response is of a different level of magnitude. So far, even in this very early stage, 900 people, including 260 children, have been killed by Israeli air strikes in Gaza, according to Palestinian authorities.

It’s not useful to wave this complexity away by saying “both sides” are responsible for violence. The actions of the Israeli government – even Netanyahu’s abysmal administration – are not equivalent to Hamas. The strikes are a response to an original attack. They seek to dismantle a terror group, no matter how crudely. That is different to Hamas, whose founding charter encourages genocide.

But that does not necessarily make them moral or sensible. The government is bombing a confined area without an established safe passage route into Egypt or the West Bank. Power and water have been cut off. Whichever way you cut it, that is a mass punishment.

Those Palestinian children are not any less dead because of the events in Israel this week. Their deaths are not made less of a tragedy. We cannot deafen ourselves to suffering in Gaza because of atrocities against Israel, any more than we should ignore atrocities against Israel because of suffering in Gaza.

The Israeli government says it intends to eliminate Hamas as an organisation. That is the morally right thing to do. It is the only possible sane response to what has taken place. But punishment bombing does not achieve that. Its toll on human lives is too great. And it creates the psychological and emotional conditions for more terrorism, going on decades into the future.

The idea of the Iron Wall entered Zionist thought through the revisionist Ze’ev Jabotinsky in 1923. A Jewish homeland, he said, could only survive “behind an iron wall, which the native population cannot breach”.

Jabotinsky was a complex, nuanced figure, many of whose ideas – particularly on binationalism – would be considered far too liberal for those in the Netanyahu regime today. But there is one central fact about his belief in the Iron Wall: it does not work.

The latest version is a smart fence, using the newest technology, deploying more than 140,000 tons of iron and steel as well as hundreds of cameras, radars and sensors. In 2021, Defence Minister Benny Gantz said it was an “iron wall” between Hamas and southern Israel. On Saturday, Hamas broke through.

Part of the horror we feel is because of the sense of grim inevitability around what is happening, one which hurts all the more because of that realistic suspicion that Hamas planned for and desires Israel’s response – that it wants an end to Israeli talks establishing relations with Arab nations, a larger war to flare up, a groundforce to enter Gaza and the whole litany of disasters which will follow from that fact.

There is another way. It is not about iron walls, but mutual advancement. Hamas can be eradicated through a strategy that minimises the harm to Palestinian civilians. A safe Jewish homeland can exist alongside Palestinian self-determination through a political process.

Right now, these ideas seem hopeless. They seem barely more than a whisper in a thunderstorm. But they cannot be given up on, even when they appear impossible. Because without them, there is only horror – an endless cycle of death and revenge, the scale of it so great it threatens to overwhelm the senses.

title: Rishi Sunak’s dreadful smoking ban is his most dangerous policy yet
lead: It’s authoritarian, legally muddled, pointless and potentially self-harming
author: Ian Dunt

body.text: Rishi Sunak just banned smoking. He didn’t say that and it will not initially feel like it, but it’s what he has done.

During his conference speech today he pledged to raise the legal age of smoking by one year, every year, in such a way that someone who is 14 years old today will never be able to legally buy a cigarette. In other words, it is a phased-in ban which will eventually encompass everyone, of the sort recently passed in New Zealand.
The policy will be popular. People in this country hate cigarettes and they are very fond of banning things. But it is also wrong, both practically and on point of principle.

It is a policy in search of a problem. Over the course of several decades, teen smoking has gone into terminal decline to the point where it is on the verge of ceasing to exist. In 2021, the proportion of school pupils who regularly smoked had dropped to just 1 per cent. The decline is happening at speed. It was double that – 2 per cent – in 2018.
Back in 1996, 30 per cent of 15-year-olds regularly smoked. That figure fell to 5 per cent in 2018 and had hit just 3 per cent in 2021.

This is not the pattern we see in other forms of drug use, where a ban is in place. Britain’s Misuse of Drugs Act has now been in place for over half a century. In 1971, when it was passed, fewer than 10,000 people in the UK took heroin. Now 250,000 do. Under half a million took cannabis, whereas now 2.5 million do. Around 1 per cent of adults had tried drugs in the 1960s, compared to a third today.

There is a profound disconnect in many progressive circles about the notion of banning things. If you talk about the war on drugs, there is a progressive consensus that it has failed. Any liberal minded person worth their salt likes to stress what a catastrophic policy it has been. And yet when you talk about draconian policies on tobacco, the realisation seems to fall away.

I suspect it’s about categories. “The war on drugs” conjures up an image of a policeman with a truncheon arresting a harmless teenager. “Cigarettes” conjure up the image of big tobacco – huge multinational companies putting their profits above people’s health. It inverts the assumed power dynamic in people’s minds, turning it from a social justice issue to an anti-corporate one.

But when you put those mental categories aside, the basic principle is exactly the same. Bans are ineffective when they are applied to things that people often want to do. And drugs, in whatever form they take, are things that people often want to do. We have taken drugs for so long, and in so many cultures, that they must be considered effectively inseparable from the human experience.

Sunak has therefore done the worst thing at the worst time. He has taken youth smoking decline, an area of supreme national accomplishment, and applied a policy which represents a supreme national failure. It would be one thing if he had instigated this ban when teen smoking rates were sky high. But to do it when they are on the verge of extinction is irresponsible in the extreme.

The ban will not function like any other law we know of. When we ban drugs – as Home Secretary Suella Braverman did recently with laughing gas – we simply slap it on the existing schedule. It’s banned for everyone, regardless of age. But Sunak’s ban will be age dependent.

Previously, we’ve only needed cards to show we are over 18 years old, an easy and well-understood threshold. What happens when today’s 14 year old is 41? How can they be distinguished from someone who is 43? Will we be carrying identity cards throughout our lives to demonstrate our exact age? What happens when someone comes from overseas? Will tourists need them too?

These are not insurmountable problems. But they are significant ones, with fairly wide personal and commercial implications. And they are being introduced to solve a problem which is anyway disappearing if the Prime Minister would just leave it alone.
For all that, the point is not simply practical. It is also about a principle – with all drugs and with this drug in particular.

It is not the state’s job to tell you what you can and cannot consume. That’s the case for cannabis in the UK today, or for alcohol in the US during prohibition, or for cigarettes in the UK tomorrow. Smoking is a very dangerous thing to do. But people have the right to make up their own minds about the level of risk and pleasure they want in their lives. Eating burgers and chips every day is also a dangerous thing to do, as is driving, or having unprotected sex, or playing rugby. But you can make your own choices about how to live life. It is not the state’s job to do so for you.
Sunak’s cigarette ban is authoritarian, legally muddled, pointless and potentially self-harming. It will be popular. But it is wrong.

title: The Tories are lost to lunatic conspiracy and moral obsolescence (not that Rishi Sunak cares)
lead: There is really no depth to which they will not sink
author: Ian Dunt

body.text: The Conservative Party conference is a circus of idiocy, conspiracy theory, vacuity and mendacity.

It’s like watching the death of a living brain. You can barely assimilate one act of egregious political irresponsibility before another one comes along to distract you. It comes from junior politicians and senior ones, from those who always had a wide-eyed kamikaze look about them and those who should damn well know better.

Take Thérèse Coffey, Secretary of State for the Environment, Food and Rural Affairs. She’s been in government, on and off, for over a decade. And yet in her conference speech on Monday she started wittering away like a bona fide maniac.

“There are some green zealots who think our farmers should stop rearing livestock and instead we should eat fake meat,” she said. “Fake meat may be OK for astronauts, but when people think of a meat feast I want them to be thinking of our great Welsh lamb.”

What was she talking about? No one knows. What would come next from her mouth? No one could possibly guess. She was lost in a deranged fantasy land of meat products, fighting against imaginary enemies on an invented soil.

Something has happened here. Through some bizarre twist in the normal political narrative, senior Conservatives are spending their time imagining political assaults on the concept of meat. And it has been left to them, the last redoubtable defenders of sausages and burgers, to wield the shield against this nefarious vegan conspiracy.

“It’s no wonder Labour seem so relaxed about taxing meat,” Claire Coutinho, Secretary of State for Energy, said in her speech. “Sir Keir Starmer doesn’t eat it and Ed Miliband is clearly scarred by his encounter with a bacon sandwich.” This is what passes for knee-slapping, choke-on-a-canape humour in the conference circuit. The only problem is: there is no proposal for a meat tax. Starmer has never advocated it.

Sky’s Sophy Ridge put that point directly to Coutinho 10 times during a subsequent interview. The Energy Secretary didn’t blink an eye. It was as if the concept of objective truth, of a world that exists outside the senses, simply did not exist to her.

Over at the event organised by the IEA and Taxpayers’ Alliance “think-tanks” – at this point we have to use that designation with heavy quotation marks – Conservative MP Danny Kruger was expanding the conspiracist world view into previously unimagined domains. The political world he described was more akin to a  cartoon than something you’d expect from a parliamentarian.

Why had the Conservatives achieved so little in government? He had a ready answer to that. “The penny is dropping among people in Westminster that the Government doesn’t run the Government,” he said. Utter gibberish.

“There’s a huge movement going on globally to create essentially a world government that will have power to dictate to national governments what they should do in anticipation of another pandemic,” he went on.
On the main stage, Mark Harper, Secretary of State for Transport, was pursuing his own invented battles. The Conservatives, he said, would stop the “misuse of 15-minute cities”.

These are plans to create communities in which work, shopping, healthcare and leisure are reachable in a short walk or cycle ride. This is to improve the environment, boost public health and create elegant urban centres. In the dread lunacy of the post-Covid internet sewer, it has been turned into a conspiracy theory about governments stopping people from leaving their homes.

Instead of refuting that conspiracy theory, he actively encouraged it. “What is sinister, and what we shouldn’t tolerate,” Harper told delegates, “is the idea that local councils can decide how often you go to the shops.” He had taken the worst elements of the deranged sections of the anti-lockdown movement and fully ingested it into departmental policy. He had successfully closed the gap between himself and a madman writing all-caps lunacy on an online forum.

Over at the Conservative Friends of Israel event, London mayoral candidate Susan Hall, went one better. “I know how frightened some of the community is because of the divisive attitude of Sadiq Khan,” she said of Jewish people. “We need to defeat him, particularly for our Jewish community.”

There is not one single record of Khan ever saying anything remotely antisemitic. He has been a proud defender of Jewish people for his entire time as London mayor. “Throughout his tenure as mayor, Sadiq Khan has treated our community with friendship and respect,” the Board of Deputies of British Jews said. “There is no fear present at all.”

There is really no depth to which they will not sink. The conference is awash with the basest instincts of political life: lies, fictions, conspiracy theories and the perpetual stoking of invented division. There’s no sense that ministers might propose a useful idea to improve people’s lives. There’s no hint that they might grapple with the problems which actually affect the country. Instead, they are lost in some mad world of dimwittery and moral obsolescence.

Once upon a time, not so long ago, any one of these comments would have drawn censure from the leadership – a forced resignation, or a slap on the wrist, or at least some distancing from No 10. But we’re way past that point now. In certain cases, such as the meat tax and the 15-minute city nonsense, the material comes directly from government.

The age in which Tory politicians felt shame, or believed that they must at least pay lip-service to the truth, or in which they might have felt embarrassed to associate themselves with the furthest extremes of the anti-lockdown movement, are over. They’ll say anything. They’ll make up any old nonsense. And when called on it, they’ll just press on ahead with what they’re saying, as if none of it had ever happened.
And surely it must be that way. Because if they could feel shame, if they could genuinely recognise what it is they have become, they wouldn’t be able to live with themselves.

title: This was the best conference the Labour Party has had in 20 years
lead: I have never seen a more positive, upbeat, disciplined, highly-organised operation
author: Ayesha Hazarika

body.text: When I arrived at Labour Party conference late on Saturday night there was chaos at the taxi rank at Liverpool station. Huge queues and no discernible system. “Thought Labour were going to clear the backlog,” I muttered grumpily to the person next to me.

However, that was pretty much the last glimpse of any disorder to be seen because to say the conference management was a tight ship is an understatement. In four years, it’s gone from a human jumble sale to a well-oiled political machine.

In fact, in all my near 20 years coming to Labour Party conference as a political adviser in government, then opposition and now as a journalist, I have never seen a more positive, upbeat, disciplined, highly-organised operation. Apart from the glitter bomb, but we’ll come to that.
Everywhere you went from the main conference hall to the fringe meetings to the late night parties – every staffer, adviser, MP, councillor, Lord and parliamentary candidate was bang on message.
Such is the rigour of party management, no one is allowed to call their own mum without clearance from a young, strict adviser let alone blab to a journalist after a few warm proseccos.

So nervous were some wannabe MPs, that they did the whole conference without touching a drop. One former die-hard party animal told me “No way am I risking making a f**k up and facing the wrath of Morgan”, Starmer’s all powerful senior political Svengali, Morgan McSweeney. Some may say that’s over the top, but this gives you a sense of the hunger there is to win at every level of the party and the fear of messing it up.

Everyone was singing from the same hymn sheet and that included union and business leaders. It was striking how many lobbyists, businesses and suits were there from the city and the fact that the brothers and sisters from the trade union movement were totally okay with that.

I asked many a general secretary if they were uncomfortable with the bosses being here in full force and even they were pitch perfect: our members and our economy needs thriving businesses but they need committed happy workers.

Even many businesses leaders told me that, given that labour shortages and staff retention were one of their biggest issues, they wanted to have good relations with their workers and trade unions. But why all this weird political kumbaya?

Because pretty much every part of society is fed-up with the state of the country and wants a change of government as soon as possible – from your city slicker to your gnarly union bruiser (although in reality, the city boys are much “woker” these days and this generation of union leader are more pragmatic).

Add to that the turnout from civic society and there was this overwhelming sense of unity and purpose from pretty much every attendee at conference. And everyone is prepared to toe the line to get Sir Keir Starmer over the line.

People accept that they may not get everything they want right now, but they will compromise to get the Tories out. Things may change if Labour wins and people may start making impossible demands, but that’s tomorrow’s problem.

That shared ambition is also reflected in the vast amounts of money flowing into Labour’s coffers from extremely wealthy individuals, many of them former industrialists and entrepreneurs. I met a few and asked them why? What was in it for them? A peerage or policy strings?

They all said they were so rich, they had everything they needed, but they wanted a change. Again, very on message. But on a serious note, all this money and support means Labour is getting properly tooled up for this general election.

The organisation, stakeholder support and money is all in good order. But what about the raw politics? Starmer’s freshly reshuffled Shadow Cabinet are talented, ambitious, hardworking and smart. Leading the charge was Rachel Reeves who had a belter of a conference. She has brought business back to Labour and she is a powerful player at the top of the party.

Her barnstormer of a speech made me feel she was the political love child of Gordon Brown and Margaret Thatcher – the first female Iron Chancellor. Her weighty speech which was rich in economics and big politics was in stark contrast to Jeremy Hunt’s 15-minute affair last week.

She is selling herself as custodian of the public purse. Perhaps one of the biggest “cut-through” policy moments of conference was her menacing promise to get back all the money from corrupt Covid contracts. It was clear that no one is spending a penny without her say so.

The Shadow Cabinet rose to their feet to applaud her but looked petrified as they did so. Everyone is thrilled but terrified of Reeves in equal measures. She’s so subliminally powerful I only realised I was wearing the same blue trouser suit she wore on the day of her speech when we got into the same lift. “Nice suit,” she remarked.If glitter boy had tried it on when she was on stage, he would have probably ended up in hospital.
There is no doubt that the security lapse and that protester dominated coverage of Starmer’s big speech. But the glitter incident gave him an opportunity to shine. He reacted and recovered well.
