One aide quipped “We prepared for every protest group – from situation in the Middle East to Just Stop Oil and Extinction Rebellion. Nowhere on my risk register was some form of PR. I guess the good thing is that after all this, there’s no way Keir’s ever going to do it…”

Starmer’s speech recovered and the hall absolutely loved it. While there were no big policy rabbits in the hat, there was a narrative around rebuilding Britain and a very clear message that he was very different from the many Tory prime ministers who went before him.

This a working-class man who understood the indignity of what it was like to be ignored or held back but who had worked hard and risen up. His use of the word “service” was a signal of his hinterland – a commitment to working for the public good as former Director of Public Prosecutions. An offer to the public that he and his team would work for them not themselves.

The horrific events in Israel were also a big test for him to define himself against Jeremy Corbyn and show the world that the party really was under new management, which he passed. But there was also a recognition that no matter how much the party faithful loved his speech, because of the enormity of these events, the public would hear very little about the content.
His confidence has grown and the suits have got better. And that often tricky end of speech moment with the spouse could not have gone better.

His wife Lady Victoria is no doubt a huge asset. They look great together and clearly quite like each other, which helps. While mercifully she didn’t introduce him, her presence was important. People want to see their potential future leaders in a human context and their partners are part of that story whether you like it or not. Her appearance was subtle but choreographed. She wore a Labour red dress which was specially loaned to her by London based, Canadian-British designer Edeline Lee. They have “regular people” level of appeal. As someone remarked “They just look like a really nice, normal couple. If they lived on your street, you would want to know them.” Someone else (a bloke obviously) had a rather more basic take “he’s well punching”. Hey, don’t shoot the messenger.

If you’re keen on Labour, you loved it all. If you’re a don’t-know, Starmer and the party still have to persuade you why you should pick them and spell that out clearly. There is still a long way to go on detailed policy, although I wouldn’t hold your breath. I suspect the Tories will go long with the next election. They feel their polling numbers may go up if the economy recovers even slightly and that Labour’s will fall once the scrutiny of a general election is upon them. And no prime minister ever wants to leave Downing Street. I think we are looking at an election even as late as December 2024. Much can happen in that time including the two by-elections coming up soon.
But there is no doubt that the feeling of confidence and momentum is with Labour. You could feel it crackle in the air. “Things Can Only Get Better” blared out at every reception on the last night.

As tired, hungover senior advisers and politicians checked out of the conference hotel, there was a sense of accomplishment. They wanted to look like a government in waiting but they may have even exceeded expectations. A veteran political watcher remarked “this lot look more like the actual government than the cult who gathered in Manchester last week.”

title: The Tory conference is just like New Labour’s end days – funereal, chaotic and out of time
lead: There’s a distinct stench of quiet, inexorable political decay. I remember it well when I was a special adviser for Labour in 2009
author: Ayesha Hazarika

body.text: “Go on… Is it as mad as it looks from the outside?” That’s the same message I’ve had from my political friends not as lucky as me to make it to the Tory party conference. The answer is a disappointing no.

Last year, with the mayhem of Liz Truss and the mini-Budget, Tory conference was like a political zoo in an exhilarating kind of way. It was genuinely extraordinary to see normally quite sensible Tories marauding around all the late-night parties desperate to sound off about how the lunatics have taken over the asylum. Except this year, they are the ones in charge and it’s not going so well.

The atmosphere isn’t frantic or charged (apart from a brief drive-by from Truss) – it’s “funereal”, a word which was used several times to me by several political observers. There’s a stench of quiet, inexorable political decay.

It felt like there were far fewer people there than in previous years. A colleague was shocked to be able to get a seat in the normally bustling Midland hotel bar on the Sunday afternoon. But that’s what happens when you lose 1,000 local councillors – important foot-soldiers who would have often brought their families along. There just wasn’t any crackle in the air.

I recall a few years back when Theresa May was prime minister but Boris Johnson was very much on manoeuvres. Everywhere he went there was a media scrum and phones being whipped out for selfies. This year on two occasions we were told to stop and wait as someone important was coming and only afterwards did we even realise it was Rishi Sunak.

This is his first conference as Prime Minister and is probably the last one for the party in power. Last night, someone was frantically looking for a phone charger in the bar saying “I’m losing power…”
“Aren’t we all love”, quipped a jaded local party member.

You can tell when a party is coming to the end of its time in government. I remember it well when I was a special adviser for the Labour Party back in 2009. You feel out of time, out of ideas and out of control.

Just look at HS2. The spectacular mishandling of the Prime Minister’s announcement over its fatesays it all. That the news is still dribbling out painfully while the party gathers in a former railway station in Manchester with a strapline about taking long-term decisions is beyond farcical. Watching the West Midlands Tory Mayor, Andy Street, host an impromptu press conference to launch a personal mission to save the Manchester leg with private money added to the chaos.

Labour, by the way, should work with Street on this. I wouldn’t be surprised if he ended up leaving the party or even defecting over this fiasco. Every Tory is mortified by HS2 now. The most charitable explanation I heard was that Sunak wants to get it off the books to clear the way for some tax cuts, but even that feels like a stretch.

And what about the big ideas for the country? A pick-and-mix of random ideas that don’t just fail to weave any coherent narrative, but actively contradict each other. Banning mobile phones in the classroom to protect kids (nanny state), but adults are free to run kids over outside schools because we need to end the war on cars. I’m hoping Sunak’s big policy announcement will be fitting all schoolchildren with airbags.

It was also notable to see how the role of the chancellor has been so reduced. Back in the day, George Osborne’s speech would be agenda-setting both in terms of policy and politics. Now we have Jeremy Hunt reduced to rehashing old austerity retreads like going after benefits and the Civil Service and making sure Nigel Farage has a bank account.

It was ironic that Hunt made Barbie and Ken gags, because he’s clearly a man with no political balls right now. Word is that Prime Minister Sunak is also very much still chancellor and rules the roost. I guess old habits die hard and he is technically First Lord of the Treasury.

This conference isn’t about Sunak. He looks like this is the last place on Earth he wants to be. He dashes in and out of events as quickly as possible leaving no trace. He pulled out of drinks with political editors. He basically hates it and the party faithful can tell. After all, they didn’t vote for him.

One of the under-reported aspects of the conference is that not all members are weird terrible caricatures. I was struck by how many activists old and young alike are deeply frustrated by the party’s lack of offer to a new generation and want to have sensible conversations about issues like housing. But that’s not what this conference is about.

It’s not even about losing the next election with dignity. It’s about what and who comes next. Everyone is jostling for position although some more crassly than others. One senior figure told me, “Suella has basically been pre-loading her leadership bid which has made her look desperate.”

Others may be doing it with a touch more subtlety, but be under no illusions. The next Tory leadership race is almost upon us. As a weary grandee observed: “This feels like the calm before the storm.”

title: No matter our achievements, men like Laurence Fox will always judge us on how ‘shaggable’ we are
lead: It’s not just ‘locker-room boy talk’, it’s out and proud and on national television
author: Ayesha Hazarika

body.text: There was a piercing clarity as Laurence Fox and Dan Wootton sniggered, smirked and giggled about not wanting to shag journalist Ava Evans which laid out so many things. One,that GB News really is the blocked toilet of British broadcasting, platforming some of the nastiest voices on the right. There are big, meaty, ideological discussions from right wing thinkers challenging the personal, political and indeed the philosophical which do deserve a hearing. “Maaate… I wouldn’t even wanna shag ‘er” is not one of them.

But that moment also reminded women that no matter how old or young you are, whatever your background, your professional accomplishments or your lived experiences or stories – it will always boil down to whether some bloke wants to have sex with you. That is your sole worth.

Let me explain. Not being shaggable is your first sin. But it can get worse. If they deem you to be shaggable but you don’t want to shag them back – ooof, well, you’re in some trouble now. At this stage, they’ll either U-turn faster than Rishi Sunak round a heat pump and suddenly reclassify you as an old boiler (combi presumably) who they wouldn’t touch with a barge pole, or if you believe those pesky “feminist” statistics, they could attack and kill you. No cute punchline line there. It often goes back to the maxim – men are scared that women are going to laugh at them, women are scared they’ll get killed.

Women being reduced to what some man would like to do to them is not just about sex or violence. It’s also about male power structures. If your boss or the men in charge think you’re hot, you’re more likely to get the job, promotion, gig, role, or show. That’s why so many women panic about growing older and hitting 40 because that’s when they commit the cardinal sin of being “unf***able” in the eyes of the architects of society who are still mainly men (apart from some very brutal female-hating women’s magazine editors).

And there’s no escape. Even if you’re a serious older woman in, let’s say the world of politics, who has never sought to use her looks or sexuality to make a point, you’re still fair game. My former boss Harriet Harman was and is a fierce feminist politician who has campaigned for a range of issues to help women from childcare provision to tougher sentences for domestic violence and rape. Here’s what Rod Liddle opined in  in 2009 “Harriet Harman then. Would you? I mean after a few beers obviously, not while you were sober.”

I was recently at a briefing about American politics where someone quipped: “Hilary reminded men of their first wife, and why they left her for a much younger, hotter one.” Cue much mirth from the mainly male audience. And who could forget the blistering speech which former Australian Prime Minister Julia Gillard made in 2012, triggered by the misogyny she had experienced, much of it centred on her body including a menu which offered “Julia Gillard Kentucky Fried Quail – small breasts, huge thighs and a big red box.”

Some of you may be thinking this is all about looks and attractiveness, and if only that were true. The most mind-blowing case of “I wouldn’t shag her” was deployed earlier this year on social media (so hard to believe I know) against… wait for it… Margot Robbie. Yes. You read that correctly. Margot Robbie is a woman so blessed with the highest level of Hollywood (Caucasian) beauty that she was allowed to play friggin Barbie. And yet, she was told by some dude on the internet in his mum’s basement that she was a “mid” and that there were “hotter” babes about than her and that they “could do better.” If Barbie is now “unshaggable” what hope do the rest of us have with these most kind noblemen?

So maybe we ladies/rabid feminazis should grudgingly thank the sewer that was the Wootton/Fox double act for something. It’s now clear for all to see in glorious technicolour – everyday sexism is alive and well. We aren’t imagining it. It’s not in our pretty, stupid heads. We’re not even being gaslit anymore. It’s no longer “locker-room boy talk”, it’s out and proud and on national television. Although is it any surprise really? Look who they put in the Whitehouse a few years ago and may soon make his comeback.

title: Labour conference: Rachel Reeves’s plan is full of populist promises which won’t fix our public services
lead: Reeves’s speech lacked any commitment to spend more on day-to-day spending on public services
author: Andrew Fisher

body.text: The eye-catching moment of Shadow Chancellor Rachel Reeves’s speech was popular in the conference hall:  announcing she would stop ministers from flying on private jets when they could fly with the public.

It was also uncharacteristically populist for Reeves, who has built her image as the iron-clad ex-Bank of England economist who you can trust with public money. “Who do you think you are, Rishi?”, she might have added.

Equally popular with delegates was her commitment that as Chancellor she would appoint an anti-corruption commissioner to recoup billions of pounds lost to fraud and waste during the Covid pandemic. Reeves estimated the losses at £7.2bn – all of which would have been signed off by the Treasury under then Chancellor, now Prime Minister, Rishi Sunak.

The new anti-corruption commissioner would bring together HM Revenue & Customs, the Serious Fraud Office and the National Crime Agency to go after fraudsters. Reeves told conference: “That money belongs in our NHS, it belongs in our schools, it belongs in our police and conference – we want that money back.” Conference responded with a standing ovation.
Indeed we do, but that money is a one-off, and even if partially reclaimed (aides quoted £2.7bn as a feasible figure) it may still take years to recover.

What Reeves’s speech lacked was any commitment to more day-to-day spending on public services. With NHS waiting lists at record levels, social care lacking 165,000 staff, teacher recruitment targets missed year after year, councils collapsing around the country, and 600,000 more children living in poverty since 2010, there is a huge and urgent need to fund our public services.

On the eve of conference, the former shadow chancellor John McDonnell and I published a report, setting out the scale of the challenge facing Britain’s battered public services. We conservatively estimate £70bn extra a year is needed just to meet existing need, clear backlogs and plug gaps. So far, Labour has committed around £5bn in tax rises – made up of ending non-dom status, closing the private equity loophole and ending some tax perks for private schools.
Labour’s response, as set out by Keir Starmer to the BBC’s , and articulated forcefully by Reeves in her speech, is “growth”.
Getting the UK economy growing at a higher level is essential: in the 15 years since the banking crash, it has managed just a 1.05 per cent increase in average annual growth.

The only good news about such low growth is that there is plenty of scope for increasing it. The bad news is that the UK’s growth has been sluggish and its productivity poor for deeply ingrained reasons – a major part of which is underinvestment. Analysis by the IPPR shows that since 1995, UK public investment has never even reached the average level of other G7 countries or the OECD club of developed economies. Reeves is right to focus on that.

But even if Labour can boost UK growth by one per cent above current forecasts (no mean feat), the Institute for Fiscal Studies cautiously estimates that will only bring in another £12.5bn a year in revenues – far short of what it needed. And it is not clear how Labour could achieve even that until its investment is fully on stream and has taken effect.
Reeves recognises this, euphemistically warning conference that there would be “tough decisions … [we] can’t push through programmes divorced from our current economic situation”.
Growth was emphasised again and again, with Reeves telling rather more subdued delegates: “You cannot tax and spend your way to growth.”

That is arguable, but what you definitely can do is tax and spend your way to better public services until growth kicks in. A few at the top and several big businesses have done very nicely while most Britons have faced stagnant wages and falling living standards. Immense wealth has amassed in too few pockets. The case has never been stronger for redistributive taxation.

Any shock to the economy, from pandemics to wars and natural disasters, could impede growth and even limit Labour’s borrowing under their fiscal rules. The £28bn commitment made by Labour in 2021 was no arbitrary figure, but calculated on the independent Climate Change Committee’s estimate that the UK needed to spend between one per cent and two per cent of GDP until 2050 to get to net zero. Based on figures at the time, that equated to between £19bn and £39bn a year.

By the time Labour gets into government next year those figures will be in the region of £25bn to £50bn, so £28bn will really be at the lower end – and since then the Climate Change Committee has warned that the Government is off-target (and therefore needs to do more).

In her closing remarks, Reeves mentioned “rescuing public services”, but her speech offered nothing in terms of delivering that rescue. With public services crumbling across the country, Labour delegates departed without a credible answer to how the crises in our public services will be resolved.

title: Labour’s by-election win in Scotland is nothing to do with Keir Starmer
lead: This morning Labour feels a step closer to government
author: Andrew Fisher

body.text: The result in Rutherglen and Hamilton West seemed like a foregone conclusion. The SNP is racked by in-fighting and scandal, their popular leader resigned and their former MP was ousted through scandal. This was a seat regained by Labour under Jeremy Corbyn in 2017 too, but lost in 2019.

The margin of the result, however, was not expected by all. One Labour MSP I spoke to earlier this week said “We will win … but not with a massive majority”. Another counselled greater optimism, saying they would be “shocked if we didn’t win well”.

In the end the latter proved right – Labour won with a 20 per cent swing from the SNP – but the tales from the doorstep were remarkably similar. “Not a lot of enthusiasm for anyone” (reflected in the low turnout), “exasperation with incumbents” (the SNP in Holyrood and the Tories in Westminster). Labour is winning in Scotland, as in England, simply by being less disliked than their opponents. And that is enough to carry Labour into government next year.
A Labour swing on this scale across Scotland at the next general election could yield 30-plus seats for Labour, with each gain taking the pressure off the party in England.

The collapse of the Conservative vote in this by-election (from 15 per cent to under 4 per cent – the party lost its deposit) also bodes well for Labour. In Scotland, and especially in and around Glasgow, the Tory vote is a unionist vote: less aligned with economics, and therefore can transfer to Labour as an anti-nationalist vote.

When New Labour was racking up successive election victories in 1997, 2001 and 2005 – it was virtually weighing on the vote in Scotland: winning 56 out of 72 seats in 1997 and 41 seats out of 59 in 2005. Even in 2010, when Labour’s vote collapsed to just 29 per cent nationally (lower than in any post-war election except 1983), the party held its 41 seats.

The tables had begun to tip in 2007 when the SNP narrowly won the Scottish Parliamentary elections for the first time. England paid little attention until the earthquake of the 2015 general election – when the SNP swept the board with 56 MPs. Labour was reduced from 41 MPs to just one. But 16 years of SNP Government in Scotland later and it feels like Friday’s result is not just a blip, but a sustained downward trajectory.

Earlier this year, former First Minister Nicola Sturgeon resigned. She was a popular, iconic and charismatic leader – and a good media performer to boot. There was no natural successor and the race to fill her shoes was uninspiring and fractious; revealing just what a broad coalition – from social conservatives to social democrats – the independence banner had held together.

In his first electoral test – a tough one to be fair – Humza Yousaf has failed. Labour canvassers tell me words like “hapless” and “not a leader” came up. The problem for the SNP is that Yousaf was the best of the bunch.

If that’s the big national picture, then the local picture was no better for the SNP. In 2020 Margaret Ferrer, the then SNP MP for Rutherglen & Hamilton West, travelled by train from London to Scotland despite having received a positive Covid test. The SNP suspended the whip and eventually called for her to stand down. Instead, she clung on as an independent until a recall petition forced this week’s by-election.

Winning a by-election caused your own party’s scandal is difficult. I recall the supreme effort it took for Labour to narrowly hold Peterborough in 2019 after the jailing of Fiona Onasanya, but Labour lost Hartlepool in 2021 after Mike Hill resigned following allegations of sexual harassment.
“The SNP membership are pretty pissed off and don’t seem to be out campaigning in Rutherglen in big numbers”, a Labour MSP said.

The independence movement has lost its mojo. Labour activists smell blood, and all wings of Labour report their campaign in Rutherglen and Hamilton West was well-organised with hundreds of activists flocking to the south Lanarkshire constituency. This is in contrast to reports of campaign dysfunction in Hartlepool in 2021 and in Uxbridge and West Ruislip earlier this year.

However, there still are nagging doubts among Labour activists. The SNP are in a lull, the Tories in a deep fug, and in by-elections Labour can mobilise activists across constituency boundaries and borders (dozens of English MPs and activists campaigned in Rutherglen). But in a general election the task will be left to local activists, the SNP may be in a better place, and their attacks on Labour being too indistinct from the Tories may begin to hit home.

But this morning Labour feels a step closer to government. Their opponents are in disarray of both sides of the border. Labour may not be inspiring, they may not be loved, but the feeling is – as one voter told a Labour canvasser – “we’ll give you a go, but don’t mess it up.”

title: Jeremy Hunt is wrong about people on benefits – but cruelty is the point
lead: The Chancellor follows a long tradition of vindictive, divisive politicians who use scapegoats to distract from their own abject failings
author: Andrew Fisher

body.text: Unemployment is rising: up by 159,000 over the last three months, and up 240,000 on a year ago. Youth unemployment is up 61,000 in the last three months and by 154,000 on a year ago.

And like clockwork, a Conservative minister is today scapegoating people on benefits. Chancellor Jeremy Hunt will tell party conference in Manchester today: “Whilst companies struggle to find workers, around 100,000 people are leaving the labour force every year for a life on benefits.”

The Conservative Party has historically found a section of the working class to isolate and demonise: it can be trade unionists going on strike, single mothers, disabled people or the unemployed. It doesn’t matter who; the point is to divide working class people so they blame each other rather than realise their common enemy is a Conservative Party making a mess of the economy and our public services.

When unemployment was rising in the 1980s, Norman Tebbit told the unemployed to “get on your bike”. Margaret Thatcher and Peter Lilley through the 1980s and 1990s demonised single mothers. They portrayed unionised workers defending their jobs and pay as “the enemy within”.

In the 2010s, the toxic combination of George Osborne and Iain Duncan Smith – cheered on by their Liberal Democrat coalition partners (Nick Clegg chimed in with his own speech about “alarm clock Britain”) – attacked people on benefits again, making the sanctions regime more punitive, while counterposing “shirkers” against “workers” or “strivers” against “skivers”.

Hunt’s claims about companies struggling to find workers and people leaving the labour force are not even remotely true – but when has this Conservative Government of inveterate liars ever worried about that? Far from companies struggling to find workers, they are cutting the number of vacancies in the economy and increasing lay-offs; they are not struggling for workers at all. The number of vacancies in the UK economy has fallen for 15 consecutive months.

The former chief economist at the Department for Work and Pensions, Jonathan Portes, commented this morning: “This is deliberately dishonest from Jeremy Hunt. 100,000 people are not ‘leaving the labour force for a life on benefits’. The increase in caseloads since the pandemic has been driven by an increase in the number certified – by DWP – as unable to work because of disability.”

A large number of those will be among the 7.7 million stuck on NHS waiting lists for treatment. Jeremy Hunt should know this. The latest Labour Market Statistics show over 2.6 million are economically inactive because they are long-term sick – that’s up from 2.1 million pre-pandemic. Over the same period, NHS waiting lists have increased by more than 60 per cent. Many of us will know of friends, neighbours or relatives that are precisely in this situation: stuck on benefits because they’re waiting for an operation.

If Hunt genuinely wanted to reduce the number of people on out of work benefits, he would be announcing significant investment in the NHS to reduce waiting times; free skills training for people on benefits; and increasing investment in job-creating projects like HS2 and housebuilding, rather than cutting them back.

Besides, if any country was going to have people giving up work and living on benefits, the UK would be the last one where it would happen: we have the least generous welfare system in Western Europe.

In 1967, UK unemployment benefit was worth 28 per cent of average earnings. Today it is worth less than half that. If unemployment benefit was paid at 28 per cent of average earnings today it would be worth over £180.00 per week instead of the miserly rate of £84.80.

That may sound generous, but let me take you across the Irish Sea where unemployment benefit is €220 per week (or £190.66 per week). And the Irish benefits system is less generous than that in Germany or France. The UK has abnormally low benefit rates that make a mockery of the phrase “social security”.

Hunt will also claim today that Labour has “pledged to end sanctions, removing the incentive to look for a job”. The incentive to look for a job is about personal dignity and fulfilment, to escape the poverty of Britain’s benefit system and harassment of the conditionality regime. More sanctions are not the answer.

Sanctions should end. They don’t work. If they did, the UK would have the most vibrant labour market in the world, but we don’t: we have high levels of economic inactivity (in large part because the Tories have made a mess of the NHS) and are bang average in the G7 for unemployment.

Most importantly of all: the Department for Work and Pensions knows that sanctions don’t work. Earlier this year, they suppressed the publication of internal research that showed exactly that, before being forced to publish in April.

Dr David Webster is an academic at Glasgow University specialising in social security who helped force the release of the DWP study, and said at the time: “The internal study shows that for the average claimant, sanctions damage both work prospects and earnings. You can see why ministers wanted to keep the report quiet.”

Hunt will today attack people out of work and advocate something his Government knows to be counterproductive. In doing so he follows a long tradition of vindictive, divisive politicians who use scapegoats to distract from their own abject failings.
Why help people when you can demonise them? That’s the Conservative way.

title: The highest tax burden since 1948 is the Tories’ biggest identity crisis yet
lead: The identity crisis is giving Suella Braverman and other MPs an opportunity to make their case
author: Isabel Hardman

body.text: Rishi Sunak wants to use the Tory party conference, which starts this weekend in Manchester, to give his party and the country some “hard truths”. But here’s one hard truth that you probably won’t hear the Prime Minister dwelling on when he takes to the stage on Wednesday: the Tories have ended up being the party of high taxes.

Yes, that’s the pre-conference assessment of the Institute for Fiscal Studies, which on Thursday warned that by the end of this parliament, the tax burden will be at a post-war high, at about 37 per cent of national income. This isn’t a blip, either, according IFS Director Paul Johnson, who says “in my view this is almost certainly a permanent increase in taxes”. Yikes. Not something you’ll hear Sunak reciting in a list of Tory achievements.

But it’s a problem that Conservative MPs and ministers have been talking noisily about for months. They see the high tax burden as the most acute expression of a wider party identity crisis, and some are dismissive of the argument from Sunak and his chancellor Jeremy Hunt that it is “virtually impossible” to cut taxes at the moment when the government’s priority has to be fighting inflation.

Liz Truss will be at the conference making the argument for lower taxes, and while activists might dismiss her as the woman who people still shout about on the doorstep, her points remain potent in the party and will be repeated in other fringe meetings by MPs who never thought she was suitable to be Prime Minister.
“We need at least an indication from Jeremy and Rishi that they don’t think high taxes are something Conservatives can be relaxed about,” says one former minister.
They said: “Fine, we’re not going to get any commitments at conference but what we still need and have been asking for for well over a year now is a sense of urgency.”

It’s not simple. Growth is sluggish, which makes it hard to find the cash. So does high public spending, and while Sunak regularly complains that people, including his own MPs, have come to think the Government has a role in everything, he also knows that there are huge spending areas that he simply cannot touch, such as the NHS.

Sunak and Hunt are similar Conservatives in many ways: they are both technocrats without a particular political mission. Hunt is very loyal to his boss and doesn’t have the same agenda that many ambitious chancellors (including Sunak when he held the role) have.

He also tends to defer to the PM more than other chancellors (including, once again, Sunak) have done in the past. To a certain extent, their political philosophy can be defined as “getting things done properly”, which in fairness is a pretty ambitious goal at the moment. But it also means that beyond the hard truths, we are unlikely to get a speech or an overall conference that gives us much of an idea of what kind of Conservatism this current party represents, other than a confused one.

It’s not just tax. Part of the Prime Minister’s vision for this autumn is of him as a slayer of monsters that other politicians have allowed to grow far beyond their original size. Changing the way Britain meets its net zero commitments was one example, while Sunak’s desire to prune HS2 in some way is another.

Neither are straightforward, either – they reflect the identity crisis in a party which for a few years had a green tree as its logo and which is still claiming to be levelling up the UK, including the city where it is holding its conference. Does it still care about giving the north of England the same infrastructure as the south-east and London, or is it retreating to a defensive crouch over the Home Counties come the next election? Do you vote blue to go green, or is green the colour of the left?

The identity crisis gives other leading figures such as Suella Braverman an opportunity to make their case. The One Nation group of Tories doesn’t have many red lines, but leaving the European Convention on Human Rights is one of them, and the Home Secretary’s threat on that this week horrified its members, including ministers who she has to work with. She is more interested in the soul-searching that might come after an election, but the Prime Minister’s lack of authority means Braverman can get her campaign started now, rather than waiting for a defeat and another leadership contest.

Boris Johnson, who bears a big responsibility for the huge tax burden, had his own approach to Tory identity. In the run-up to the 2019 general election, he booted out MPs who disagreed with him on Brexit, and ensured that the candidates who stood for the party all agreed with his “get Brexit done” pledge.

But Sunak isn’t that kind of politician, and none of the issues, not even net zero, are sufficiently visceral to enable that kind of purge. Not only that, but Johnson was removing people he saw as a barrier to Brexit. The barrier to lower taxes is, in the eyes of many Conservative MPs, the leader himself.

title: Rishi Sunak is trying to do what Nick Clegg did in 2010 – but he’s forgetting one vital point
lead: It’s a bold move
author: Isabel Hardman

body.text: Was Rishi Sunak onto something really important in his net zero press conference this week? No, not the changes the Prime Minister announced to measures tackling climate change, but something else he seemed equally agitated about.

He spent a fair bit of his hastily-rearranged address to the nation complaining about the state of politics, about short-termism, and about the way in which measures to tackle climate change had barely been scrutinised by MPs, let alone the public at large. He said: “I know that they dislike Westminster game-playing, the short-termism and the lack of accountability.”

Parts of the speech sounded a bit like Nick Clegg in the 2010 leaders’ TV debates, where he decried the state of two-party politics and charmed voters by claiming “the more they attack each other, the more they sound exactly the same”.
This was opposition, anti-politics Clegg, rather than responsible in-government Clegg, or indeed the new tech bro Clegg who Sunak would probably quite enjoy hanging out with.
Either way, Sunak is in government, whereas Clegg wasn’t at the time, so it was much easier for a Lib Dem leader few had really heard of to attack the state of politics.

Like Clegg, Sunak wants to posit himself as the change candidate in the looming general election, with Labour representing lazy consensus and a failure to be honest with the electorate, a status quo in the form of disruptive strike action, and so on. It’s a bold move.

Voters do dislike all the things Sunak listed, but so far he has shown no real inclination to make the fundamental changes that would answer that yearning for change. Why is there such a lack of accountability in politics?

Part of the reason is ambitious backbenchers stay loyal to the Government, even when they know there is a problem with a Bill because they understandably want to progress their career and have greater influence by joining the Government.

The conflict of interest in legislators wanting to join the executive they are supposed to be holding to account is something one of his closest aides and my former colleague James Forsyth was very alive to when he was at  .

He often wrote about the need for a formal separation of powers, or at least for experienced politicians who had been ministers to see the value in staying in the Commons after high office so they could help their successors avoid making mistakes. The chances of his conviction making it into reality are pretty slim, though.

Sunak complained this week that the last carbon budget process was “debated in the House of Commons for just 17 minutes and voted through with barely any consideration given to the hard choices needed to fulfil it”. He said he wanted Parliament to consider the plans to meet the carbon budget at the same time in any future votes.

Fine, but is he really also proposing making more time available for MPs to examine government policies? The current conduct of the Government suggests not. Even though he was rushed into unveiling his net zero changes a day early, he had always been planning to make that announcement when Parliament was in recess, meaning MPs didn’t have the chance to debate it at all. The Speaker of the House of Commons was furious, issuing an unusually forthright statement in which he said that if he had the power, he would recall the House.

The Prime Minister would never offend his colleagues by saying this, but the public are anyway quite aware that the calibre of politicians isn’t what it should be. There are lots of reasons for this, not least that many talented people wouldn’t want the weird, often dysfunctional life of an MP.

But it is also the case that even the talented folk who do make it into the Palace of Westminster are ill used by a culture that doesn’t reward them performing what should be one of the primary functions of their job: scrutiny.

Keir Starmer likes to complain about “sticking plaster politics” too, which is less of a surprise coming from the Leader of the Opposition than it is from the man in power. But even he only wants to talk about reforming the House of Lords rather than any proposals to make the House of Commons work better.

That’s because a weak Commons where MPs don’t bother to read or understand legislation before whizzing through a short debate on it suits the people in power, at least in the short term. In the long term, of course, the problems that might have been raised earlier by a stronger legislature end up biting the government that introduced them.

At this autumn’s conference, Sunak wants to tell his party he is the one prepared to speak hard truths. But a hard truth he doesn’t seem to be prepared to confront himself is that all the things he complains about will just keep happening unless he is prepared to make himself less powerful.

title: Abuse of Power by Theresa May review: Ex-PM leaves no stone unturned, except when it comes to her own failings
lead: In this crisply written book, Theresa May accepts her premiership will be remembered for her failure to deliver Brexit. But we are all only self-aware up to a point
author: Isabel Hardman

body.text: Theresa May’s first speech as Prime Minister promised to tackle the “burning injustices” of society, so perhaps it’s no surprise that her book, , returns to that topic after her premiership was mired in Brexit misery.

Like all ex-prime ministers, she has a few scores to settle, and a few points she wants to make for the record. Unlike her immediate predecessor David Cameron, who actually gave his memoirs the title , she doesn’t seem that interested in recording the day-to-day experience of being in power.

In fairness, not many people would want to recollect in great detail the trauma of that hamstrung parliament, the indicative votes, the weird fairground atmosphere of a Westminster filled with screaming pro- and anti-Brexit protesters. Instead, May has written about the cases of abuse of power she encountered in office. Some are well-understood: Hillsborough, sexual harassment, Windrush, Russia’s illegal invasion of Ukraine and so on.

Others are more surprising: as well as arguing that there was an abuse of power from a number of figures, including Commons Speaker John Bercow, while she attempted to lead the country through Brexit, she accuses the US of an abuse of power in its withdrawal from Afghanistan “by acting in its own interests”.

She finds several themes. One was that people in power rode roughshod over bereaved, injured and traumatised people “because they could”. Many of the chapters finish with that refrain. Another is the desire of public sector institutions to protect their reputations rather than the people they purport to serve.

May tries to be as reflective as possible, accepting that her premiership will largely be remembered for her failure to deliver Brexit, and that the 2017 election in which she lost the Conservative majority was her mistake. But of course we are all only self-aware up to a point, and I wonder whether she might also reflect that some might see an attempt at abuse of power in the very act of calling the election.

The  wrote this up as “crush the saboteurs”, and those around May boasted at the time of a huge majority that would allow them to do as they pleased. Anyway, the British public clearly thought she didn’t deserve as much power as she already had.

Her travails after losing that majority were also not blameless. The reinstatement of the Conservative whip to two men accused at the time of serious sexual impropriety (since proven in court) – Charlie Elphicke and Andrew Griffiths – represented an abuse of power: it was given back to them so they could back her in the vote of no confidence in 2019.

But that’s human nature: even the most self-reflective among us misses things others spot. May’s book is fascinating and crisply written, but it does also suffer from a narrow view of human nature itself: her diagnosis of the problems we have is strong and detailed, her analysis of why they have happened quite good, but her prescription for how to stop abuses of power in the future is weak because it relies too heavily on an assumption that more people could develop the commitment to service she clearly sees as a core part of her identity.

Her concluding chapter is entitled, and while it is very good on how too many politicians are careerists and how Parliament doesn’t work to improve the skills or behaviour of its occupants, she is possibly too idealistic about what motivates most people.

Not everyone has the quiet and serious vicarage upbringing May recalls fondly in this book. Indeed, most have a more complex mix of altruism and a desire to be praised and paid well, motivating us to do all kinds of jobs, whether it be MPs, doctors or other public servants.

That May has more seriousness and commitment than the average politician is one of the reasons she hasn’t bustled out of Parliament to earn money elsewhere, like some of her fellow ex-PMs. It also means she has a better chance to fix some of those burning injustices this book shows she is clearly still worried about.

title: UK inflation: ‘Still more work to do’ Treasury minister Andrew Griffith admits
lead: Inflation did not fall in the year to September as many observers expected
author: Eleanor Langford

body.text: A Treasury minister has admitted that there is ‘still more work’ on bringing down inflation after figures remained unchanged.
Inflation stayed flat at 6.7 per cent in the year to September, showing no change in the previous rate recorded in August.
Forecasters had predicted a slight fall in inflation, but higher petrol costs and the price of hotel stays resulted in the rate staying put, according to the ONS.
Inflation has been falling ever since it peaked at 11.1 per cent at the end of 2022, and the Government has pledged to halve inflation by the end of 2023.

Speaking to GB News on Wednesday, Treasury minister Andrew Griffith said the Government had always admitted that halving inflation “would be challenging”, but said the latest figures were “broadly in line with expectations”.
“There’s still a quarter left to go, we will see some of the benefits of the continuing reduction in energy prices,” he said.
Mr Griffith continued: “Of course, in the UK we protected households to a larger extent than in the US. We helped people more with their energy bills.

“We helped more people during Covid and we’re paying some of the price of that, but it was the right decision that we took to protect people then and it’s why we continue to make difficult but responsible decisions to bear down on inflation.
“That plan is working as shown by today’s figure, but there is still more to do.”

Food and non-alcoholic drink prices fell by 0.1 per cent between August and September, the first drop for two years. The largest driver of lower food inflation was falls in the price of staples such as milk, cheese, eggs and soft drinks.
Core inflation – which measures inflation without food and energy prices – dropped from 6.2 to 6.1 per cent, according to the figures released on Wednesday.

Commenting on the figures, Chancellor Jeremy Hunt said: “As we have seen across other G7 countries, inflation rarely falls in a straight line, but if we stick to our plan then we still expect it to keep falling this year.
“Today’s news just shows this is even more important so we can ease the pressure on families and businesses.”
The disappointing figures raise questions about the Bank of England’s next decision on interest rates in November, with rates currently standing at 5.25 per cent.
Many financial analysts expect the central bank to leave borrowing costs on hold at its next policy meeting in November.
The Bank of England’s target rate for inflation is 2 per cent, but the UK is not expected to reach this until around 2025.

title: What time is PMQs today? When Rishi Sunak will face Prime Minister’s Questions as conflict in Gaza intensifies
lead: After a recess for party conference season, it is business as usual in the Commons including the return of PMQs today
author: Sally Guyoncourt

body.text: As party conference season comes to an end it’s back to business in Parliament and with it the return of Prime Minister’s Questions.
After almost a month of recess in the House of Commons while conferences for each of the main political parties took place across the country, life has resumed at Westminster.
And a key part of that is the traditional weekly face-off between Rishi Sunak and the Labour leader Sir Keir Starmer.
Parliament went into recess on Tuesday 19 September ahead of the party conferences and returned on Monday 16 October.
So today will see the first Prime Minister’s Questions (PMQs) in almost a month at its usual time of midday, lasting for around 30 minutes.
It is an opportunity for the Prime Minster and the Leader of the Opposition to debate the biggest issues of the past week, and for MPs to put questions to the Prime Minister.
PMQs in the Commons Chamber is a ticketed event, with via their Member of Parliament or a member of the House of Lords.
The session is also televised so the public has the opportunity to watch proceedings.
Likely to be top of the agenda in the House of Commons today will be the situation in Israel and Gaza, and inflation.
The Office for National Statistics (ONS) released official figures this morning revealing inflation has remained flat at 6.7 per cent in the year to September.
Forecasters had predicted a slight fall but higher petrol costs and the price of hotel stays resulted in the rate staying put, according to the ONS.
Core inflation, which measures inflation without food and energy prices, dropped from 6.2 to 6.1 per cent, according to Wednesday’s figures.
Earlier this year, Rishi Sunak pledged to halve inflation by the end of 2023, meaning it would sit at just above 5 per cent by December.
The conflict between Israel and Hamas escalated overnight with the attack on a hospital in Gaza, reported to have killed at least 500 people.

Foreign Secretary James Cleverly said the destruction of al Ahli hospital had resulted in a “devastating loss of human life” and insisted the UK would work to “protect innocent civilian lives in Gaza”.
US President Joe Biden has already arrived in Israel on a diplomatic mission and the Prime Minister is expected to travel to there this week.

title: Tamworth by-election: First electoral test looms for Keir Starmer’s green-belt building plan
lead: Labour will need to overturn a Tory majority of nearly 20,000 to win – housing campaigners fear failure could see the party retreat from its policy
author: James Ball

body.text: Keir Starmer’s plan to encourage housebuilding on parts of Britain’s green belt will receive its first electoral test tomorrow as voters go to the polls in the Tamworth by-election.

The bookies have made Labour favourites to win, but to do so Sir Keir’s party will have to overturn a Tory majority of nearly 20,000 and the Conservatives are hopeful one of his key policies will work in their favour.
Tamworth sits on the edge of the West Midlands green belt, a point that Tory candidate Andrew Cooper has been emphasising.

“Keir Starmer has already vowed to concrete over the green belt in communities like ours, there’s a real risk that a vote for Labour is a vote to lose our green belt,” the 41 year-old told a local news website.
“Rishi Sunak has ruled out building on the green belt and I’ll work with him to stop Labour’s threat.”
The candidate – a former sniper in the Staffordshire Regiment – has set up his own survey for residents to help “stop uncontrolled development on our green belt”.

Construction of new housing is a source of tension in the area. An estate agent at Taylor Cole in Tamworth – who did not want to be named while discussing politics – told : “If there’s new housing in Tamworth it’s on fields, so it tends to be controversial.
“There’s lots of green belt here. People will sell up and move because there’s going to be a development near them.
“But people move to Tamworth to live in the new builds. So there’s people that want them, clearly. It’s definitely a hot-button issue here.”
Two doors down from that estate agent is the campaign office for Labour candidate Sarah Edwards – a bright red storefront blazoned with her name, photo and five election pledges for the area.
As a group of Labour volunteers set off to go doo- knocking – the third such group of the day – the door of the officer opens to reveal an internal wall covered with handwritten notes of support.

The Conservatives have made the fact that Ms Edwards is not from the constituency another key attack line. She is originally from Moseley, a Birmingham suburb 25 miles away. However, she now lives and pays council tax in Tamworth.

But a Labour staffer for the candidate said that in his experience residents did not seem to care very much that Ms Edwards wasn’t originally from the town: “I spoke a voter yesterday who said, ‘She could be from Timbuktu for all I care as long as she’s visible and doing the job.
The staffer noted that the Conservatives’ original candidate for the general election was a sitting MP in another seat, who was not himself from Tamworth.
“Lots of people who live in Tamworth weren’t born in Tamworth. Sarah is from West Midlands, lives here and will stay here if she loses – she’ll be the general election candidate.”

Labour’s volunteer canvassers were keen to stay on message, with more than one repeating the same phrase “we’re optimistic but taking nothing for granted”, adding that they were knocking on “hundreds of doors” every day.

Nationally, Labour sources have been suggesting that winning the seat will be a step too far. It might be a case of expectation management. However, Tory elections expert Lord Hayward believes Sir Keir’s promise take on Nimbys to boost housebuilding is a chink in Labour’s armour, especially in the many constituencies that include green-belt land.
“There will be a fair number of seats where [the housing policy] will not be helpful [for Labour],” he told  last week.

Housing campaigner Jonn Elledge has for years pushed for Labour to adopt policies building on some parts of the green belt and liberalise planning laws. He admits to some nervousness around the policy if Labour does not win Tamworth, given that Sir Keir largely disowned Sadiq Khan’s Ulez anti-pollution traffic scheme, after the party failed to take Uxbridge and South Ruislip.

“The green belt is insanely popular because it’s an incredibly good bit of branding,” he said. “It summons up mental images of rolling green fields, where most of it is boring arable monoculture, bleak wasteland, or even derelict industrial sites.
“This constituency is a mountain for Labour to climb – the fact we’re even discussing it is a sign of how much trouble the Tories are in.
“But that aside, obviously there must be a fear that Labour will lose its nerve on this [policy] if they don’t take the seat. It’s done it before and this leadership is incredibly cautious.”

However, even if there is local concern about Labour housebuilding, Tory candidate Mr Cooper also has to override national disillusion with Conservative governments, of which the very existence of the Tamworth by-election is a ready reminder.

The West Midlands seat had been represented by Conservative Chris Pincher since 2010. But last year, allegations that the former government whip had groped two men triggered the government crisis that saw Boris Johnson resign as Prime Minister.
Last month Mr Pincher followed, resigning from Parliament having been censured by a Commons committee.

The Conservative profile in Tamworth seems to be lower than it might be during the last few days of the campaign. In contrast to Labour’s highly visible town centre shopfront, neither of the Tories’ two publicly listed Tamworth addresses showed any sign of activity on Monday afternoon, less than 72 hours before polling day.

contacted the campaign’s organiser and its press manager to ask if there was any canvassing or similar activity to join, or if the candidate would be available for interview – and was told there were no media opportunities. A party source close to the campaign said the WhatsApp group was fairly active but the team wasn’t confident of holding the seat.

Apathy could well be a big winner tomorrow, in a seat where turnout has been below the national average in recent elections. During the course of a day in Tamworth,  saw only one sign in a window (for Ms Edwards), and potential voters seemed disillusioned with politics.

One town centre shop, Joy’s Boutique, had a window smashed in from a recent robbery, with a handwritten note over the panel appealing for witnesses and noting: “This is enough to bankrupt a sole trader small business.”

The shop’s owner Lisa told  the business across the road had caught the attack clearly on CCTV, but she hadn’t been able to convince police to come and collect it. But it hadn’t even occurred to her to try to get help from politicians, and she’s not planning to vote.
“They’re all the same, nothing ever gets better,” she said. “They make all the promises, more police or whatever, but it never happens. I’ve just given up on it.”

title: ‘I’d never do I’m A Celeb’: Labour’s Mid-Beds by-election hope takes swipe at outgoing Nadine Dorries
lead: Alistair Strathern talks about his speech impediment, plus his views on Corbyn, Blair, Dorries, and feminism
author: Patrick Strudwick

body.text: The headline in The Sun this summer was not ideal for someone trying to pull off a historic by-election win: “Wannabe Labour MP unmasked as ‘zombie’ Greenpeace zealot”. The picture was worse. Alistair Strathern, the man Labour has selected to try to snatch Nadine Dorries’s former seat in mid-Bedfordshire, smothered in white face paint, with red blood marks smeared from his mouth and black streaks trickling from his eyes. He was protesting with Greenpeace last year against the Public Order Act. They were all dressed as zombies.

The nice folk of mid-Bedfordshire – a collection of tiny towns and villages amid lush countryside – are likely not huge fans of zombies. The image jarred too with how Strathern looks out of zombie drag: smiley, svelte, and rubbery faced, with an air of maths teacher about him. (This is no coincidence. Before politics, and before working for the Bank of England, he was indeed a maths teacher).

Impressions matter in politics. And this by-election – to be held on Thursday – matters dramatically to the three main parties. Dorries, who eventually quit after not being given the peerage by Boris Johnson she expected, leaves a Conservative majority of over 24,000. This seat has been Tory since 1931. To lose it would be a kick in the kidneys to the ruling party.

A recent local poll places Labour neck and neck with the Conservatives, just ahead of the Liberal Democrats. The Conservative candidate, Festus Akinbusoye, is the current Police and Crime Commissioner for the area, but following requests by to interview him, the Conservatives said due to his “current commitments” and a “busy schedule until election night” it would not be possible.

But who is Strathern? An “eco zealot”? An Oxford-educated, Bank of England posh boy? On the surface the 33-year-old seems dependable, almost old-fashioned. There’s a whiff of corduroy about him. His manner is upbeat but a tad shy; as if he’s fought hard to be socially confident. The reason for this becomes apparent later, as he talks about his speech impediment, the bullying he received, and his attempts to overcome it. But first, politics, and that picture. Does he regret it?

“I don’t regret the protest,” he says, as we sit in a pub in Shefford with his partner Megan, who works for Greenpeace. “I regret maybe not taking a bit more time over, you know, hair and make-up – if I had known that photo would be front page.” He’s partly joking.

Although the protest was against the Public Order Bill, which was criticised for curbing the right to peaceful protest, his participation in it with Greenpeace, was spun as an eco-warrior stunt. He’s currently on unpaid leave from the Bank of England where he is the climate lead for the insurance sector. Given his dedication to climate causes, is he a vegetarian?
“No,” he says. Meat is one of the key contributors to climate change, so why not?

“Lack of moral integrity?” he replies, laughing, adding a “no” to correct his answer. You’ll definitely regret saying that, I say. “I think there’s a lot more low-hanging fruit for tackling climate change than trying to change every aspect of people’s behaviour. Tackling climate change and doing better by young people are probably my biggest two personal-political passions.”

Voters may wonder where Strathern fits within the left or right of his party, so I ask how he feels about two former Labour leaders: Jeremy Corbyn and Tony Blair. Corbyn was suspended from Labour in 2020 (and then blocked from standing as a Labour candidate) after saying the extent of antisemitism in the party had been “dramatically overstated”, following a critical report by the Equality and Human Rights Commission.

Should Corbyn be welcomed back into the party? “He is yet to apologise for the statement he put out after the publication of a report into some really shocking failings in the Labour Party under his leadership. If he’s not in a position where he can acknowledge the issues … then he has no place in a Labour party that is looking to be a party of government.” And Blair? Was it a mistake to invade Iraq? “Yes,” he replies.

Another politician looms large over the conversation: Nadine Dorries. The superfan of Boris Johnson became widely criticised over her commitment to her constituents. She didn’t speak or vote in the Commons for over a year.

Even the Prime Minister, Rishi Sunak, questioned Dorries’s commitment as a constituency MP in August: “people aren’t being properly represented”. Over the summer a large banner was strung up in Flitwick, the largest town in the area: “DOSSER DORRIES OUT”.
Dorries, for her part, told the  podcast over the summer that she and her team were “working daily with constituents”.

“There’s been a real sense that for the last few years this area has felt taken for granted,” says Strathern. “They haven’t had an MP for a long time now who has felt like they really understand and care for the community. The way Nadine behaved over the last few years, and certainly over the last few months of her tenure, felt like the last straw for lots of people who have seen politics become more and more removed from our communities – typified by someone who took such a little interest in the everyday lives of people here. And that worst stereotype of politicians who are in it for themselves.”
This impression first formed a decade ago when Dorries appeared on ITV’s  Would Strathern ever do a reality show?
I wouldn’t, but even if I wanted to my partner would kill me,” he says, with a glancing smile in her direction. So he can categorically rule out any appearances? “Categorically rule out, yes.”

The Liberal Democrats, meanwhile, could still win in Mid-Bedfordshire, with their candidate, Emma Holland-Lindsay. Strathern has attacked the Lib Dems online for wanting to “legalise drugs”. In fact, they want to decriminalise one drug – cannabis. But are the drug laws working?

“I certainly wouldn’t look to defend this government’s approach to tackling drug crime,” says Strathern, as he attacks the Tory record on combating organised crime such as county lines gangs, amid overstretched police resources. But would he defend the laws against drugs? “Yes”.
Why should police devote their limited resources to combating cannabis when rapists are walking free?

“It’s a truly sad picture of how broken law enforcement has become in this country if you are telling me it has to be an either or,” he says. “It’s so important that we up the number of rapists going to trial.

“It is shocking the low conviction rates, the low prosecution rates, and the understandable deterrence that has on women coming forward because they simply do not have confidence that this system will do right by them. But that cannot be at the expense of continuing to tackle other crime. We have to fund and resource a police force that’s able to do all of that.”
Is Strathern a feminist?
“Yes,” he replies immediately. He is less quick answering the follow-up, about whether he believes feminism should include or excludes trans people.

“What do you mean by that dichotomy?” he asks, looking uncomfortable; aware of the political minefield. I clarify my question: that, for example, some feminists see trans people as fellow victims under patriarchy, and some fear they pose a threat in women-only spaces. Which camp is he in?
“It’s about treating people as human beings, recognising, cherishing that identity and ensuring they’ve got access to all of the healthcare and guidance that that identity requires,” he says.

“But that does not mean disregarding the rights of independent groups, such as refuges, to make distinctions about who they feel they can accommodate safely within that space. I think the Equality Act provides opportunity to make distinctions based on biological gender, where certain institutions feel that it’s appropriate. And for me, it’s absolutely right that refuges have that protection to make that judgement.”

One of Strathern’s five key pledges to constituents in mid-Bedfordshire is tackling the cost-of-living crisis. So why won’t Labour commit to scrapping the cap on benefits to families with more than two children?

He begins by criticising the Conservatives, and “how tired people are of broken promises”, and the “risks of doing too much too quickly” before admitting the bind his party is in. “There are obviously things that we would like to be able to do differently,” he says. If Labour win the general election next year “the complete mess we’re inheriting will restrain our ability to deliver the full range of support we want to”. But he cites certain pledges such as “ensuring no primary school child starts [school] hungry”.

There are policies Labour could deploy that would raise money not cost the government, like increasing income tax on the highest earners. Why not do that? Strathern says they have to be “measured” in what they do and adds instead, “We will close a tax loophole that non-dom citizens benefit from. They can afford to pay more tax in this country and they should.”

And private schools? Some people are confused about what the Labour policy is, as it seemed to change from removing charitable status to now simply removing VAT exemption. Either way, he says it would mean more money to the Treasury “and that feels to me like an understandable prioritisation, making sure we’re not giving that exemption to people who pay school fees at a time when state schools are really, really struggling.”

At first glance, someone could look at Strathern’s life and think he doesn’t understand the struggles of everyday people, and when I ask about what brought him into politics, his answer about seeing vast inequality in Oxford doesn’t seem to cover it, so I begin to probe into his own life.

After his grandmother died, his grandfather came to live with the family. “It became clearer the slow grip of a dementia was taking more and more of him away,” he says. “Seeing the toll that took on him personally, but also my whole family and particularly my mum, was really, really hard.” He eventually had to be looked after in a care home, before he died. It was, says Strathern, “truly heart-breaking.”

As an adult he’s had knocks, in a more literal sense, too. In his late twenties, playing football he suffered a concussion so bad he was off work for three months. “I got quite depressed – it’s a depressing thing not to be able to spend time with your friends, not to be able to do your job, not to know if you’re going to get any better. Because to begin with it was getting worse, not better.”

Now, he wants young people to have better mental health provisions. “The capacity of the system is far below the needs,” he says, particularly with waiting times, and says if elected he will work with mental health charities to try to plug the gaps.

As we talk, there’s something I want to ask but don’t quite know how, because it’s personal. It sounds like he has a speech impediment, a rarity in the harsh world of politics, but one that affects around 1.4 million children in Britain, according to Speech and Language UK.

“Yes, I do,” he says. “I have a slight lisp. I had a much more pronounced lisp as a child. It still comes and goes – it becomes more pronounced particularly when tired and exhausted. I had speech therapy when I was growing up.”

Were kids at school calling him names? “Oh god, yeah – kids are kids. Less so at primary school.”  The bullying, he says, “became more pronounced at middle school and upper school. I became more aware of it in a negative context socially at middle school.” He describes the form this bullying took.

“Negative impressions. Hostile impressions. Physically mocking. That did stay with me. So I think for a very long time after that I was not a very confident speaker at all. There were a lot of reasons why I decided to become a teacher. But I think there was an element of wanting to prove to myself that I could be in front of people, all day every day, and I could do a profession which relied on me speaking. To force yourself to get more confident.”

“There’s no more intimidating audience,” he says, than an unruly classroom on a Friday afternoon. “There’s no more imaginative and fun group of people that want to throw insults at you.” At least going into politics, I say, he has experience of being mocked. He seems to agree. “After that,” he replies, smiling, “anything is a breeze.”

title: Hunt warned against benefit cuts as inflation set to remain over 6.5%
lead: The Government is considering increasing benefits for working-age people by less than the current rate of inflation in order to save money
author: Hugo Gye

body.text: The Government has been urged to ensure that benefits are not cut in real terms, as new figures are set to show inflation remaining over 6.5 per cent.

Internal Treasury forecasts suggest that the rate of price rises in September remained flat at 6.7 per cent,  understands – casting further doubt over whether Rishi Sunak will meet his target of halving it over the course of this year.

Core inflation, which strips out the most volatile elements of the data, is also set to be unchanged on 6.2 per cent – although food and drink inflation is expected to fall to 12.3 per cent, from its previous level of 13.6 per cent, giving some relief for shoppers.
Government officials remain hopeful of a significant fall in inflation this month, which would be reflected in data published shortly before the Chancellor’s Autumn Statement on 22 November.

The figures, made public on Wednesday by the Office for National Statistics (ONS), would normally be used to determine the rate at which working-age benefits including universal credit should rise next year.

But Jeremy Hunt is understood to be considering using a lower benchmark, possibly reflecting the expected level of inflation for the next year, to limit the cost to the Exchequer. A final decision will be announced next month.
Charity campaigners warned the Chancellor to ensure that benefits keep pace with prices so that claimants’ living standards do not fall over time.

Helen Barnard of the Trussell Trust, which runs a network of food banks, told : “We are already seeing unprecedented levels of need across the country, with more and more people facing severe hardship, and forced to turn to food banks.

“The majority of people on universal credit are already having to go without essentials, more than half have run out of food and been unable to afford more. It would be wholly wrong for the Government to break with the normal practice of uprating benefits with inflation and plunge even more people into ever deeper hardship.”

Iain Porter of the Joseph Rowntree Trust added: “The overwhelming majority of low-income households who use Universal Credit face going without enough food, or another essential. In these circumstances, how can the Government not commit to uprating benefits with the rate of inflation, as is the normal due process, to reflect the soaring costs of basic essentials?”

Real wages for working people are finally growing again after a long squeeze, the ONS has confirmed, after average pay rose by 7.8 per cent over the summer, excluding bonuses – well above the rate of inflation.
Mr Hunt said: “It’s good news that inflation is falling and real wages are growing, so people have more money in their pockets. To keep this progress, we must stick to our plan to halve inflation.”
The Government has committed to push inflation down to just over 5 per cent by the end of this year, but the rate of price rises in the UK remains higher than most comparable countries.

title: State pension triple lock under threat in Jeremy Hunt’s Autumn Statement
lead: The Chancellor is considering whether to strip out the effect of public-sector bonuses when calculating the state pension for next year
author: Hugo Gye

body.text: Jeremy Hunt is still considering whether to tweak the “triple lock” to cut the cost of the state pension for next year,  can reveal.
New inflation data published on Wednesday is set to confirm that the state pension should rise by 8.5 per cent in 2024 under the formula used by the Treasury to calculate its annual increase.
The triple lock states that each year the pension increases by the same level as average earnings or inflation, or by 2.5 per cent – whichever is the highest.

The inflation rate for September – the month used to calculate the triple lock – will be revealed on Wednesday and is forecast to be somewhere around 6.6 per cent. The annual earnings increase for May to July was 8.5 per cent – meaning that figure will be the one used to determine the rate of pensions, because it is higher than inflation.
But the earnings data was distorted by a surge in bonus payments for public-sector workers agreed by the Government to bring NHS and other strikes to an end.

The Chancellor could therefore choose to strip out the effect of bonuses from the statistics – leaving the average pay increase at 7.8 per cent. A Treasury source said: “There is still a question mark over tweaking the triple lock to exclude the massive one-off effect of payments to NHS staff.”
Such a change would be the first time the wage measure has been used with bonuses stripped out
Mr Hunt’s decision will not be officially confirmed until the autumn statement on 22 November.

If the higher figure is used, the basic state pension for new claimants will rise from £203.85 a week to £221.20. If the lower earnings figure replaces it, the Treasury will save hundreds of millions of pounds but pensioners will lose £74 a year.
Campaigners have claimed that changing the basis of the triple lock would be a breach of the manifesto promise made by the Conservatives.

The last time the triple lock was tweaked was in 2021, when average wages surged during the recovery from the pandemic, having dropped significantly in the previous year – meaning inflation was used as the measure instead.

Speaking at the Tory party conference this month, Mr Hunt indicated that he was concerned about the implications of watering down the policy. He said: “I think that we have to be very careful not to break manifesto promises… sometimes it does happen, but I think it needs to be a very exceptional circumstance where people can see that there’s a very good reason.”
However, a No 10 spokesman insisted that the Government was committed to fiscal discipline in light of a warning from the Institute for Fiscal Studies that the public finances were in a “bind”.

He said: “Driving down inflation is the most effective tax cut you can deliver right now, so we are committed to our plan to halve it and will not make the situation worse by borrowing money to fund tax cuts.”

title: Keir Starmer battling to contain growing Labour unrest over Israel-Gaza stance
lead: Labour council leaders are growing concerned over the party leadership’s comments over Gaza
author: Richard Vaughan

body.text: Sir Keir Starmer is battling to contain growing unrest among Labour council leaders over the party’s stance on the Israel-Hamas conflict.

The Labour leadership held a meeting with dozens of council leaders from across the country on Monday evening amid an increasing backlash to Sir Keir’s comments in support of Israel’s bombardment of the Gaza strip.

Shadow Foreign Secretary David Lammy and the Labour leader’s chief of staff Sue Gray met council leaders with large Muslim communities, who warned that support for the party was “in freefall” as a result of Labour’s stance on the conflict.
Several Labour councillors resigned from the party this week in protest against Sir Keir’s backing of Israel’s decision to cut all water, food and electricity into Gaza as part of a “siege”.

Among them was Councillor Amna Abdullatif, the first Muslim woman to be elected to Manchester City Council, who released a resignation statement, saying she was “appalled by the lack of humanity being shown to Palestinians by the party I have been a member of for the last 10 years”.

Ms Abdullatif added on Twitter/X: “I am devastated to now have no choice other than to resign the Labour whip and from the Labour Party due to Keir Starmer and a number of his frontbench making horrifying comments about Israel having the right to withhold fuel, water, food and electricity from the 2.2m Palestinians trapped in Gaza, effectively endorsing a war crime.”
Statement of resignation from the Labour Party, Cllr Amna Abdullatif, Manchester City Council. pic.twitter.com/8Wap2EFUjI

Two further Labour councillors on Oxford City Council also quit the party, councillors Shaista Aziz and Amar Latif, who released a joint statement saying they were “deeply disappointed and alarmed” by comments made by Sir Keir “seeming to condone the use of collective punishment against the people of Gaza”.
Ms Aziz told the : “Like all decent-minded people, we are devastated by the atrocities carried out by Hamas in Israel. However, we are appalled by the words of Keir Starmer.”

understands that some council leaders demanded the Labour leader explicitly apologise for his comments on LBC last week, when he insisted that “Israel has the right” to withhold power and water from Gaza.
Although he added: “Obviously, everything should be done within international law.”

According to those present at the emergency meeting, which was called with just two hours’ notice due to the outcry within the Association of Labour Councillors, Ms Gray and Mr Lammy said the situation in Israel and Gaza could go on for weeks.

One council leader told  there was an “extraordinary disconnect” between the Labour leadership and the party’s council leaders, with suggestions that a second meeting could be held on Tuesday evening in a bid to ease concerns.
Labour has been approached for comment.

title: Rishi Sunak asks Qatar for help in releasing British hostages and speaks to Saudi leader bin Salman about Gaza
lead: The Prime Minister is expected to travel to Israel this week, following President Biden’s visit to the region on Wednesday
author: Jane Merrick

body.text: Rishi Sunak has urged Qatar’s leaders to help secure the release of British hostages held by Hamas,  understands.
It is feared as many as 12 British or dual nationality British-Israelis were seized by Hamas gunmen in the attacks on Saturday 7 October and are being held in Gaza.
In a phone conversation with the Emir of Qatar, Sheikh Tamim bin Hamad al-Thani, on Tuesday, the Prime Minister is understood to have requested support in asking Hamas for their release.

Qatar’s leaders could play a pivotal role in the hostage crisis, as the political offices for the militant Palestinian group are based in the Gulf kingdom, giving Doha’s government a channel for potential negotiations. Qatar is regarded by the UK government as a trusted regional partner of Britain.
Mr Sunak also raised the issue of the British hostages in a separate phone call with Saudi Arabia’s Crown Prince and PM Mohammed bin Salman.
The British Prime Minister is expected to travel to Israel as soon as this week, following President Biden’s visit to the region on Wednesday.

Mr Sunak has been at the forefront of the UK’s diplomatic efforts to show support for Israel in the wake of the Hamas terror attacks and to try to limit any conflict from spilling over into a regional war.
A Downing Street spokesperson said Mr Sunak and Sheikh bin Hamad al Thani discussed how to ensure safe passage of aid to Gaza and “urgent efforts to secure the release of hostages”.

They added: “The Prime Minister reiterated his complete condemnation of Hamas’s terrorist attack and set out the UK’s efforts to support Israel and protect Palestinian civilians and British nationals caught up in the violence.
